name: dbms_file_transfer.copy_file
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER.COPY_FILE(
   source_directory_object       IN  VARCHAR2,
   source_file_name              IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination_directory_object  IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination_file_name         IN  VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure reads a file from a source directory and creates a copy of it in a destination directory. The source and destination directories can both be in a local file system, or both be in an Automatic Storage Management (ASM) disk group, or between local file system and ASM with copying in either direction.

name: dbms_file_transfer.get_file
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER.GET_FILE
   source_directory_object      IN  VARCHAR2,    
   source_file_name             IN  VARCHAR2,  
   source_database              IN  VARCHAR2,  
   destination_directory_object IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination_file_name        IN  VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure contacts a remote database to read a remote file and then creates a copy of the file in the local file system or ASM. The file that is copied is the source file, and the new file that results from the copy is the destination file. The destination file is not closed until the procedure completes successfully.

name: dbms_file_transfer.put_file
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER.PUT_FILE(
   source_directory_object       IN  VARCHAR2,   
   source_file_name              IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination_directory_object  IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination_file_name         IN  VARCHAR2,  
   destination_database          IN  VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure reads a local file or ASM and contacts a remote database to create a copy of the file in the remote file system. The file that is copied is the source file, and the new file that results from the copy is the destination file. The destination file is not closed until the procedure completes successfully.

name: dbms_flashback.disable
bodyFullText: DBMS_FLASHBACK.DISABLE;
descriptionText: This procedure disables the Flashback mode for the entire session.

name: dbms_flashback.enable_at_system_change_number
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK.ENABLE_AT_SYSTEM_CHANGE_NUMBER (
   query_scn IN NUMBER);
descriptionText: This procedure takes an SCN as an input parameter and sets the session snapshot to the specified number. In the Flashback mode, all queries return data consistent as of the specified wall-clock time or SCN. It enables Flashback for the entire session.

name: dbms_flashback.enable_at_time
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK.ENABLE_AT_TIME (
   query_time   IN TIMESTAMP);
descriptionText: This procedure enables Flashback for the entire session. The snapshot time is set to the SCN that most closely matches the time specified in query_time.It enables Flashback for the entire session.

name: dbms_flashback.get_system_change_number
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK.GET_SYSTEM_CHANGE_NUMBER
 RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function returns the current SCN as an Oracle number datatype. You can obtain the current change number and store it for later use. This helps you retain specific snapshots.

name: dbms_flashback.transaction_backout
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK.TRANSACTION_BACKOUT
   numtxns            NUMBER,
   xids               XID_ARRAY,
   options            NUMBER default NOCASCADE, 
   timeHint           TIMESTAMP default MINTIME);

DBMS_FLASHBACK.TRANSACTION_BACKOUT
   numtxns            NUMBER,  
   xids               XID_ARRAY, 
   options            NUMBER default NOCASCADE,
   scnHint            TIMESTAMP default 0   );

DBMS_FLASHBACK.TRANSACTION_BACKOUT
   numtxns           NUMBER,
   txnnames          TXNAME_ARRAY,
   options           NUMBER default NOCASCADE,
   timehint          TIMESTAMP MINTIME );

DBMS_FLASHBACK.TRANSACTION_BACKOUT
   numtxns           NUMBER, 
   txnNames         TXNAME_ARRAY, 
   options          NUMBER default NOCASCADE,
   scnHint          NUMBER 0);
descriptionText: This procedure provides a mechanism to back out a set of transactions. The user can call these procedures with either transaction names or transaction identifiers (XIDS).

name: dbms_flashback_archive.add_table_to_application
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.ADD_TABLE_TO_APPLICATION (
   application_name           IN   VARCHAR2,
   table_name                 IN   VARCHAR2,
   schema_name                IN   VARCHAR2 := NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and adds a table to the application as a security table. If the application is enabled for Flashback Data Archive, then this table will also be enabled for Flashback Data Archive.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.create_temp_history_table
descriptionText: This procedure creates a table called TEMP_HISTORY with the correct definition in schema.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.disable_application
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.DISABLE_APPLICATION (
   application_name           IN   VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and disables Flashback Data Archive on all of its security tables.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.disable_asof_valid_time
bodyFullText: DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.DISABLE_ASOF_VALID_TIME;
descriptionText: This procedure disables session level valid-time flashback.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.disassociate_fba
descriptionText: This procedure disassociates the given table from the flashback data archive.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.drop_application
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.DROP_APPLICATION (
   application_name           IN   VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and removes it from the list of applications. As part of this procedure, Flashback Data Archive will be disabled on all security-enabled tables and all history data will be lost. The group called SYSTEM cannot be dropped.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.enable_application
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.ENABLE_APPLICATION (
   application_name           IN   VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and enables Flashback Data Archive on all the security tables for this application. Once an application is enabled, every change to an FDA enabled table will be tracked.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.enable_at_valid_time
descriptionText: This procedure enables session level valid time flashback.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.extend_mappings
bodyFullText: DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.EXTEND_MAPPINGS;
descriptionText: This procedure extends time mappings to times in the past.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.get_sys_context
descriptionText: This function gets the context previously selected by the SET_CONTEXT_LEVEL Procedure.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.import_history
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.IMPORT_HISTORY (
   owner_name1         IN   VARCHAR2, 
   table_name1         IN   VARCHAR2 
   temp_history_name   IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'TEMP_HISTORY',
   options             IN   BINARY_INTEGER DEFAULT 0);
descriptionText: This procedure is called after invoking the CREATE_TEMP_HISTORY_TABLE Procedure procedure, and after the TEMP_HISTORY table is populated with user-generated history data.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.lock_down_application
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.LOCK_DOWN_APPLICATION (
   application_name           IN   VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and makes all the security tables read-only. The group called SYSTEM cannot be locked.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.purge_context
bodyFullText: DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.PURGE_CONTEXT;
descriptionText: This procedure purges the context to be saved selected by the SET_CONTEXT_LEVEL Procedure.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.reassociate_fba
descriptionText: This procedure reassociates the given table with the flashback data archive.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.register_application
descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and optionally a Flashback Data Archive, and registers an application for database hardening. When database hardening is enabled, then all the security tables for that application are enabled for Flashback Data Archive using the given Flashback Data Archive. If no Flashback Data Archive is specified, the default Flashback Data Archive is used.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.remove_table_to_application
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.REMOVE_TABLE_TO_APPLICATION (
   application_name           IN   VARCHAR2,
   table_name                 IN   VARCHAR2,
   schema_name                IN   VARCHAR2 := NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and marks a table in it as no longer being a security table. If the application is already enabled for Flashback Data Archive, Flashback Data Archive will be disabled for this table.

name: dbms_flashback_archive.set_context_level
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.SET_CONTEXT_LEVEL (
   level          VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure defines how much of the user context is to be saved.

name: dbms_frequent_itemset.fi_horizontal

	, itemset_length_min => $3
	, itemset_length_max => $4
	, including_items => NULL
	, excluding_items => NULL
bodyNoDefault:
tranx_cursor => $1
	, support_threshold => $2
	, itemset_length_min => $3
	, itemset_length_max => $4
	, including_items => $5
	, excluding_items => $6
bodyFullText:
DBMS_FREQUENT_ITEMSET.FI_HORIZONTAL(
   tranx_cursor         IN    SYSREFCURSOR,
   support_threshold    IN    NUMBER,
   itemset_length_min   IN    NUMBER,
   itemset_length_max   IN    NUMBER,
   including_items      IN    SYS_REFCURSOR DEFAULT NULL,
   excluding_items      IN    SYS_REFCURSOR DEFAULT NULL)
  RETURN TABLE OF ROW (
     itemset [Nested Table of Item Type DERIVED FROM tranx_cursor],
     support        NUMBER,
     length         NUMBER,
     total_tranx    NUMBER);
descriptionText: The purpose of this table function is to count all frequent itemsets given a cursor for input data which is in\'HORIZONTA\' row format, support threshold, minimum itemset length, maximum itemset length, items to be included, items to be excluded. The result will be a table of rows in form of itemset, support, length, total transactions counted.

name: dbms_heat_map.object_heat_map

DBMS_HEAT_MAP.OBJECT_HEAT_MAP (

name: dbms_ilm.add_to_ilm
bodyFullText:
DBMS_ILM.ADD_TO_ILM (
   task_id           IN    NUMBER,
   owner             IN    VARCHAR2,
   object_name       IN    VARCHAR2,
   subobject_name    IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure adds the object specified through the argument to a particular ADO task and evaluates the ADO policies on this object. The procedure can only be executed on an ADO task in an inactive state. The results of the ADO policy evaluation on this object can be viewed using the appropriate views depending on role and access (USER_ILMTASKS or DBA_ILMTASKS, USER_ILMEVALUATIONDETAILS or DBA_ILMEVALUATIONDETAILS, USER_ILMRESULTS or DBA_ILMRESULTS).

name: dbms_ilm.archivestatename
descriptionText: This function returns the value of the ORA_ARCHIVE_STATE column of a row-archival enabled table.

name: dbms_ilm.execute_ilm
bodyFullText:
DBMS_ILM.EXECUTE_ILM (
   task_id             OUT    NUMBER,
   ilm_scope           IN     NUMBER DEFAULT SCOPE_SCHEMA,
   execution_mode      IN     NUMBER DEFAULT ILM_EXECUTION_ONLINE);

DBMS_ILM.EXECUTE_ILM (
   owner               IN     VARCHAR2,
   object_name         IN     VARCHAR2,
   task_id             OUT    NUMBER, 
   subobject_name      IN     VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   policy_name         IN     VARCHAR2 DEFAULT ILM_ALL_POLICIES,
   execution_mode      IN     NUMBER DEFAULT ILM_EXECUTION_ONLINE);
descriptionText: This procedure executes an ADO task.

name: dbms_ilm.execute_ilm_task
descriptionText: This procedure executes an ADO task that has been evaluated previously and moves it to an active state.

name: dbms_ilm.preview_ilm
descriptionText: This procedure evaluates the ADO policies on the objects specified using the ILM_SCOPE argument. It returns a number as task_id which identifies a particular ADO task. This can be used to view the results of the policy evaluation in the appropriate views depending on role and access (USER_ILMTASKS or DBA_ILMTASKS, USER_ILMEVALUATIONDETAILS or DBA_ILMEVALUATIONDETAILS, USER_ILMRESULTS or DBA_ILMRESULTS).

name: dbms_ilm.remove_from_ilm
bodyFullText:
DBMS_ILM.REMOVE_FROM_ILM (
   task_id           IN    NUMBER,
   owner             IN    VARCHAR2,
   object_name       IN    VARCHAR2,
   subobject_name    IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure removes the object specified through the argument from a particular ADO task. The procedure can only be executed on an ADO task in an inactive state.

name: dbms_ilm.stop_ilm
descriptionText: This procedure stops ADO-related jobs created for a particular ADO task.

name: dbms_ilm_admin.clear_heat_map_all
bodyFullText: DBMS_ILM_ADMIN.CLEAR_HEAT_MAP_ALL;

name: dbms_ilm_admin.disable_ilm

name: dbms_ilm_admin.enable_ilm

descriptionText: This procedure turns on all background ILM scheduling.

name: dbms_ilm_admin.set_heat_map_all
descriptionText: This procedure updates or inserts heat map rows for all tables.

name: dbms_ilm_admin.set_heat_map_start
bodyFullText:
DBMS_ILM_ADMIN.SET_HEAT_MAP_START  (
   start_date  IN   DATE);
descriptionText: This procedure sets the start date for collecting heat map data.

name: dbms_ilm_admin.set_heat_map_table
body:
owner => $1
	, tablename => $2
	, partition => ''
	, access_date => NULL
	, segment_access_summary => NULL
bodyFullText:
DBMS_ILM_ADMIN.SET_HEAT_MAP_TABLE  (
   owner                  IN VARCHAR2,
   tablename              IN VARCHAR2,
   partition              IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT '',
   access_date            IN DATE DEFAULT NULL,
   segment_access_summary IN NUMBER DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure updates or inserts a row for the specified table or segment.

name: dbms_inmemory.populate
bodyFullText:
DBMS_INMEMORY.POPULATE (
   schema_name      IN    VARCHAR2,
   table_name       IN    VARCHAR2,
   subobject_name   IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure forces population of a given table.

name: dbms_inmemory.repopulate
body:
schema_name => $1
	, table_name => $2
	, subobject_name => NULL
	, force => FALSE
bodyFullText:
DBMS_INMEMORY.REPOPULATE (
   schema_name      IN    VARCHAR2,
   table_name       IN    VARCHAR2,
   subobject_name   IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   force            IN    BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
descriptionText: This procedure forces repopulation of a given table.

name: dbms_job.broken
bodyFullText:
DBMS_JOB.BROKEN ( 
   job       IN  BINARY_INTEGER,
   broken    IN  BOOLEAN,
   next_date IN  DATE DEFAULT SYSDATE);
descriptionText: This procedure sets the broken flag. Broken jobs are never run.

name: dbms_job.change
body:
job => $1
	, what => $2
	, next_date => $3
	, interval => $4
	, instance => NULL
	, force => FALSE
bodyNoDefault:
job => $1
	, what => $2
	, next_date => $3
	, interval => $4
	, instance => $5
	, force => $6
bodyFullText:
DBMS_JOB.CHANGE ( 
   job       IN  BINARY_INTEGER,
   what      IN  VARCHAR2,
   next_date IN  DATE,
   interval  IN  VARCHAR2,
   instance  IN  BINARY_INTEGER DEFAULT NULL,
   force     IN  BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
descriptionText: This procedure changes any of the fields a user can set in a job.

name: dbms_job.instance
bodyFullText:
DBMS_JOB.INSTANCE ( 
   job        IN BINARY_INTEGER,
   instance   IN BINARY_INTEGER,
   force      IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
descriptionText: This procedure changes job instance affinity.

name: dbms_job.interval
descriptionText: This procedure changes how often a job runs.

name: dbms_job.next_date
descriptionText: This procedure changes when an existing job next runs.

name: dbms_job.remove
bodyFullText:
DBMS_JOB.REMOVE ( 
   job       IN  BINARY_INTEGER );
descriptionText: This procedure removes an existing job from the job queue. This currently does not stop a running job.

name: dbms_job.run
descriptionText: This procedure runs job JOB now. It runs it even if it is broken.

name: dbms_job.submit
body:
job => $1
	, what => $2
	, next_date => SYSDATE
	, interval => 'null'
	, no_parse => FALSE
	, instance => any_instance
	, force => FALSE
bodyNoDefault:
job => $1
	, what => $2
	, next_date => $3
	, interval => $4
	, no_parse => $5
	, instance => $6
	, force => $7
bodyFullText:
DBMS_JOB.SUBMIT ( 
   job       OUT BINARY_INTEGER,
   what      IN  VARCHAR2,
   next_date IN  DATE DEFAULT SYSDATE,
   interval  IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'null',
   no_parse  IN  BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   instance  IN  BINARY_INTEGER DEFAULT any_instance,
   force     IN  BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
descriptionText: This procedure submits a new job. It chooses the job from the sequence sys.jobseq.

name: dbms_job.user_export
bodyFullText:
DBMS_JOB.USER_EXPORT ( 
   job    IN     BINARY_INTEGER,
   mycall IN OUT VARCHAR2);

DBMS_JOB.USER_EXPORT ( 
   job      IN     BINARY_INTEGER,
   mycall   IN OUT VARCHAR2,
   myinst   IN OUT VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: There are two overloaded procedures. The first produces the text of a call to re-create the given job. The second alters instance affinity (8i and after) and preserves the compatibility.

name: dbms_job.what
descriptionText: This procedure changes what an existing job does, and replaces its environment.

name: dbms_libcache.compile_from_remote
body:
p_db_link => $1
	, p_username => null
	, p_threshold_executions => 3
	, p_threshold_sharable_mem => 1000
	, p_parallel_degree => 1
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LIBCACHE.COMPILE_FROM_REMOTE ( 
   p_db_link                 IN     dbms_libcache$def.db_link%type, 
   p_username                IN     VARCHAR2 default null,
   p_threshold_executions    IN     NATURAL  default 3,
   p_threshold_sharable_mem  IN     NATURAL  default 1000,
   p_parallel_degree         IN     NATURAL  default 1);
descriptionText: This procedure extracts SQL in batch from the source instance and compiles the SQL at the target instance.

name: dbms_lob.append
descriptionText: This procedure appends the contents of a source internal LOB to a destination LOB. It appends the complete source LOB.

name: dbms_lob.close
descriptionText: This procedure closes a previously opened internal or external LOB.

name: dbms_lob.compare
body:
lob_1 => $1
	, lob_2 => $2
	, amount => DBMS_LOB.LOBMAXSIZE
	, offset_1 => 1
	, offset_2 => 1
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.COMPARE (
   lob_1            IN BLOB,
   lob_2            IN BLOB,
   amount           IN INTEGER := DBMS_LOB.LOBMAXSIZE,
   offset_1         IN INTEGER := 1,
   offset_2         IN INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;

DBMS_LOB.COMPARE (
   lob_1            IN CLOB  CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   lob_2            IN CLOB  CHARACTER SET lob_1%CHARSET,
   amount           IN INTEGER := DBMS_LOB.LOBMAXSIZE,
   offset_1         IN INTEGER := 1,
   offset_2         IN INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER; 

DBMS_LOB.COMPARE (
   lob_1            IN BFILE,
   lob_2            IN BFILE,
   amount           IN INTEGER,
   offset_1         IN INTEGER := 1,
   offset_2         IN INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function compares two entire LOBs or parts of two LOBs.

name: dbms_lob.converttoblob
body:
dest_lob => $1
	, src_clob => $2
	, amount => $3
	, dest_offset => $4
	, src_offset => $5
	, blob_csid => $6
	, lang_context => $7
	, warning => $8
bodyNoDefault:
dest_lob => $1
	, src_clob => $2
	, amount => $3
	, dest_offset => $4
	, src_offset => $5
	, blob_csid => $6
	, lang_context => $7
	, warning => $8
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.CONVERTTOBLOB(
  dest_lob       IN OUT     NOCOPY  BLOB,
  src_clob       IN         CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  amount         IN         INTEGER,
  dest_offset    IN OUT     INTEGER,
  src_offset     IN OUT     INTEGER, 
  blob_csid      IN         NUMBER,
  lang_context   IN OUT     INTEGER,
  warning        OUT        INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure reads character data from a source CLOB or NCLOB instance, converts the character data to the character set you specify, writes the converted data to a destination BLOB instance in binary format, and returns the new offsets. You can use this interface with any combination of persistent or temporary LOB instances as the source or destination.

name: dbms_lob.converttoclob
body:
dest_lob => $1
	, src_blob => $2
	, amount => $3
	, dest_offset => $4
	, src_offset => $5
	, blob_csid => $6
	, lang_context => $7
	, warning => $8
bodyNoDefault:
dest_lob => $1
	, src_blob => $2
	, amount => $3
	, dest_offset => $4
	, src_offset => $5
	, blob_csid => $6
	, lang_context => $7
	, warning => $8
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.CONVERTTOCLOB(
   dest_lob       IN OUT NOCOPY  CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   src_blob       IN             BLOB,
   amount         IN             INTEGER,
   dest_offset    IN OUT         INTEGER,
   src_offset     IN OUT         INTEGER, 
   blob_csid      IN             NUMBER,
   lang_context   IN OUT         INTEGER,
   warning        OUT            INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure takes a source BLOB instance, converts the binary data in the source instance to character data using the character set you specify, writes the character data to a destination CLOB or NCLOB instance, and returns the new offsets. You can use this interface with any combination of persistent or temporary LOB instances as the source or destination.

name: dbms_lob.copy
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.COPY (
  dest_lob    IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
  src_lob     IN            BLOB,
  amount      IN            INTEGER,
  dest_offset IN            INTEGER := 1,
  src_offset  IN            INTEGER := 1);

DBMS_LOB.COPY ( 
  dest_lob    IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB  CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  src_lob     IN            CLOB  CHARACTER SET dest_lob%CHARSET,
  amount      IN            INTEGER,
  dest_offset IN            INTEGER := 1,
  src_offset  IN            INTEGER := 1);
descriptionText: This procedure copies all, or a part of, a source internal LOB to a destination internal LOB. You can specify the offsets for both the source and destination LOBs, and the number of bytes or characters to copy.

name: dbms_lob.copy_dbfs_link
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.COPY_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc_dst    IN OUT BLOB,
  lob_loc_src    IN     BLOB,
  flags          IN     PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT DBFS_LINK_NOCACHE);

DBMS_LOB.COPY_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc_dst    IN OUT CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  lob_loc_src    IN     CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  flags          IN     PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT DBFS_LINK_NOCACHE);
descriptionText: This procedure copies the DBFS Link in the source LOB to the destination LOB.

name: dbms_lob.copy_from_dbfs_link
descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the archived SecureFiles LOB data from the DBFS HSM store and to the database.

name: dbms_lob.createtemporary
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.CREATETEMPORARY (
   lob_loc IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
   cache   IN            BOOLEAN,
   dur     IN            PLS_INTEGER := DBMS_LOB.SESSION);
  
DBMS_LOB.CREATETEMPORARY (
   lob_loc IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   cache   IN            BOOLEAN,
   dur     IN            PLS_INTEGER := 10);
descriptionText: This procedure creates a temporary BLOB or CLOB and its corresponding index in your default temporary tablespace.

name: dbms_lob.dbfs_link_generate_path
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.DBFS_LINK_GENERATE_PATH (
  lob_loc       IN BLOB,
  storage_dir   IN VARCHAR2) 
 RETURN VARCHAR2;
 
DBMS_LOB.DBFS_LINK_GENERATE_PATH (
  lob_loc       IN CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  storage_dir   IN VARCHAR2) 
 RETURN VARCHAR2;
descriptionText: This subprogram returns a unique file path name for use in creating a DBFS Link.

name: DBMS_LOB.dbms_lob
descriptionText: This function returns TRUE if the LOB locator passed to it is for a SecureFile LOB. It returns FALSE otherwise.

name: dbms_lob.erase
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.ERASE (
   lob_loc           IN OUT   NOCOPY   BLOB,
   amount            IN OUT   NOCOPY   INTEGER,
   offset            IN                INTEGER := 1);

DBMS_LOB.ERASE (
   lob_loc           IN OUT   NOCOPY   CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount            IN OUT   NOCOPY   INTEGER,
   offset            IN                INTEGER := 1);
descriptionText: This procedure erases an entire internal LOB or part of an internal LOB.

name: dbms_lob.fileclose
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FILECLOSE (
    file_loc IN OUT NOCOPY BFILE);
descriptionText: This procedure closes a BFILE that has already been opened through the input locator.

name: dbms_lob.filecloseall
bodyFullText: DBMS_LOB.FILECLOSEALL;
descriptionText: This procedure closes all BFILEs opened in the session.

name: dbms_lob.fileexists
descriptionText: This function finds out if a specified BFILE locator points to a file that actually exists on the serve\'s file system.

name: dbms_lob.filegetname
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FILEGETNAME (
   file_loc   IN    BFILE, 
   dir_alias  OUT   VARCHAR2,
   filename   OUT   VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure determines the directory object and filename, given a BFILE locator. This function only indicates the directory object name and filename assigned to the locator, not if the physical file or directory actually exists.

name: dbms_lob.fileisopen
descriptionText: This function finds out whether a BFILE was opened with the specified FILE locator.

name: dbms_lob.fileopen
descriptionText: This procedure opens a BFILE for read-only access. BFILE data may not be written through the database.

name: dbms_lob.fragment_delete
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_DELETE (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
   amount      IN            INTEGER,
   offset      IN            INTEGER);

DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_DELETE (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount      IN            INTEGER,
   offset      IN            INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure deletes the data at the specified offset for the specified length from the LOB without having to rewrite all the data in the LOB following the specified offset.

name: dbms_lob.fragment_insert
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_INSERT (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
   amount      IN            INTEGER,
   offset      IN            INTEGER,
   buffer      IN            RAW);

DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_INSERT (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount      IN            INTEGER,
   offset      IN            INTEGER,
   buffer      IN            VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
descriptionText: This procedure inserts the specified data (limited to 32K) into the LOB at the specified offset.

name: dbms_lob.fragment_move
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_MOVE (
   lob_loc       IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
   amount        IN            INTEGER,
   src_offset    IN            INTEGER,
   dest_offset   IN            INTEGER);

DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_MOVE (
   lob_loc       IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount        IN            INTEGER,
   src_offset    IN            INTEGER,
   dest_offset   IN            INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure moves the amount of bytes (BLOB) or characters (CLOB/NCLOB) from the specified offset to the new offset specified.

name: dbms_lob.fragment_replace
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_REPLACE (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
   old_amount  IN            INTEGER,
   new_amount  IN            INTEGER,
   offset      IN            INTEGER,
   buffer      IN            RAW);

DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_REPLACE (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,   old_amount  IN           INTEGER,
   new_amount  IN           INTEGER,
   offset      IN           INTEGER,
   buffer      IN           VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
descriptionText: This procedure replaces the data at the specified offset with the specified data (not to exceed 32k).

name: dbms_lob.freetemporary
descriptionText: This procedure frees the temporary BLOB or CLOB in the default temporary tablespace.

name: dbms_lob.get_dbfs_link
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc             IN     BLOB,
  storage_path        OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  lob_length          OUT NUMBER);

DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc             IN     CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  storage_path        OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  lob_length          OUT NUMBER);
descriptionText: This function returns the DBFS path name for the specified SecureFile LOB.

name: dbms_lob.get_dbfs_link_state
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE (
  lob_loc       IN BLOB,
  storage_path  OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  state         OUT NUMBER,
  cached        OUT BOOLEAN);

DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE (
  lob_loc       IN CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  storage_path  OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  state         OUT NUMBER,
  cached        OUT BOOLEAN);
descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the current link state of the specified SecureFile.

name: dbms_lob.get_storage_limit
descriptionText: This function returns the LOB storage limit for the specified LOB.

name: dbms_lob.getchunksize
descriptionText: When creating the table, you can specify the chunking factor, a multiple of tablespace blocks in bytes. This corresponds to the chunk size used by the LOB data layer when accessing or modifying the LOB value. Part of the chunk is used to store system-related information, and the rest stores the LOB value.

name: dbms_lob.getcontenttype
descriptionText: This procedure returns the content type string previously set by means of the SETCONTENTTYPE Procedure.

name: dbms_lob.getlength
descriptionText: This function gets the length of the specified LOB. The length in bytes or characters is returned.

name: dbms_lob.getoptions
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GETOPTIONS (
   lob_loc             IN     BLOB,
   option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER) 
 RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
 
DBMS_LOB.GETOPTIONS (
  lob_loc             IN     CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER) 
RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function obtains compression, deduplication, and encryption settings corresponding to the option_type field for a particular LOB.

name: dbms_lob.instr
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.INSTR (
   lob_loc    IN   BLOB,
   pattern    IN   RAW,
   offset     IN   INTEGER := 1,
   nth        IN   INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;

DBMS_LOB.INSTR (
   lob_loc    IN   CLOB      CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   pattern    IN   VARCHAR2  CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET,
   offset     IN   INTEGER := 1,
   nth        IN   INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;

DBMS_LOB.INSTR (
   file_loc   IN   BFILE,
   pattern    IN   RAW,
   offset     IN   INTEGER := 1,
   nth        IN   INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function returns the matching position of the nth occurrence of the pattern in the LOB, starting from the offset you specify.

name: dbms_lob.isopen
descriptionText: This function checks to see if the LOB was already opened using the input locator. This subprogram is for internal and external LOBs.

name: dbms_lob.istemporary
descriptionText: This function determines whether a LOB instance is temporary.

name: dbms_lob.loadblobfromfile
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.LOADBLOBFROMFILE (

   src_bfile   IN            BFILE, 
   amount      IN            INTEGER, 
   dest_offset IN OUT        INTEGER, 
   src_offset  IN OUT        INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure loads data from BFILE to internal BLOB. This achieves the same outcome as LOADFROMFILE, and returns the new offsets.

name: dbms_lob.loadclobfromfile

	, src_bfile => $2
	, amount => $3
	, dest_offset => $4

	, src_bfile => $2

	, warning => $8

name: dbms_lob.loadfromfile

DBMS_LOB.LOADFROMFILE (

name: dbms_lob.move_to_dbfs_link
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc       IN OUT BLOB,
  storage_path  IN     VARCHAR2(dbfs_link_path_max_size),
  flags         IN     BINARY INTEGER DEFAULT DBFS_LINK_NOCACHE); 

DBMS_LOB.MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK (

name: dbms_lob.open
descriptionText: This procedure opens a LOB, internal or external, in the indicated mode. Valid modes include read-only, and read/write.

name: dbms_lob.read
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.READ (
   lob_loc   IN             BLOB,
   amount    IN OUT  NOCOPY INTEGER,
   offset    IN             INTEGER,
   buffer    OUT            RAW);

DBMS_LOB.READ (
   lob_loc   IN             CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount    IN OUT  NOCOPY INTEGER,
   offset    IN             INTEGER,
   buffer    OUT            VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET); 

DBMS_LOB.READ (
   file_loc   IN             BFILE,
   amount    IN OUT   NOCOPY INTEGER,
   offset    IN              INTEGER,
   buffer    OUT             RAW);
descriptionText: This procedure reads a piece of a LOB, and returns the specified amount into the buffer parameter, starting from an absolute offset from the beginning of the LOB.

name: dbms_lob.set_dbfs_link
descriptionText: This function links the specified SecureFile to the specified path name. It does not copy the data to the path.

name: dbms_lob.setcontenttype
descriptionText: This procedure sets the content type string for the data in the LOB.

name: dbms_lob.setoptions
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.SETOPTIONS (
   lob_loc             IN     BLOB,
   option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER,
   options             IN     PLS_INTEGER);
 
DBMS_LOB.SETOPTIONS (
  lob_loc             IN     CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER, 
  options             IN     PLS_INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure enables/disables compression and deduplication on a per-LOB basis, overriding the default LOB column settings.

name: dbms_lob.substr
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.SUBSTR (
   lob_loc     IN    BLOB,
   amount      IN    INTEGER := 32767,
   offset      IN    INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN RAW;

DBMS_LOB.SUBSTR (
   lob_loc     IN    CLOB   CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount      IN    INTEGER := 32767,
   offset      IN    INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET;

DBMS_LOB.SUBSTR (
   file_loc     IN    BFILE,
   amount      IN    INTEGER := 32767,
   offset      IN    INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN RAW;
descriptionText: This function returns amount bytes or characters of a LOB, starting from an absolute offset from the beginning of the LOB.

name: dbms_lob.trim
descriptionText: This procedure trims the value of the internal LOB to the length you specify in the newlen parameter. Specify the length in bytes for BLOBs, and specify the length in characters for CLOBs.

name: dbms_lob.write
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.WRITE (
   lob_loc  IN OUT NOCOPY  BLOB,
   amount   IN             INTEGER,
   offset   IN             INTEGER,
   buffer   IN             RAW);

DBMS_LOB.WRITE (
   lob_loc  IN OUT  NOCOPY CLOB   CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount   IN             INTEGER,
   offset   IN             INTEGER,
   buffer   IN             VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
descriptionText: This procedure writes a specified amount of data into an internal LOB, starting from an absolute offset from the beginning of the LOB. The data is written from the buffer parameter.

name: dbms_lob.writeappend
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.WRITEAPPEND (
   lob_loc IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB, 
   amount  IN            INTEGER, 
   buffer  IN            RAW); 

DBMS_LOB.WRITEAPPEND (
   lob_loc IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS, 
   amount  IN            INTEGER, 
   buffer  IN            VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
descriptionText: This procedure writes a specified amount of data to the end of an internal LOB. The data is written from the buffer parameter.

name: dbms_lock.allocate_unique
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOCK.ALLOCATE_UNIQUE (
   lockname         IN  VARCHAR2,
   lockhandle       OUT VARCHAR2,
   expiration_secs  IN  INTEGER   DEFAULT 864000);
descriptionText: This procedure allocates a unique lock identifier (in the range of 1073741824 to 1999999999) a specified lock name. Lock identifiers are used to enable applications to coordinate their use of locks. This is provided because it may be easier for applications to coordinate their use of locks based on lock names rather than lock numbers.

name: dbms_lock.convert
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOCK.CONVERT(
   id         IN INTEGER || 
   lockhandle IN VARCHAR2,
   lockmode   IN INTEGER,
   timeout    IN NUMBER DEFAULT MAXWAIT)
  RETURN INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function converts a lock from one mode to another. CONVERT is an overloaded function that accepts either a user-defined lock identifier, or the lock handle returned by the ALLOCATE_UNIQUE procedure.

name: dbms_lock.release
descriptionText: This function explicitly releases a lock previously acquired using the REQUEST function. Locks are automatically released at the end of a session. RELEASE is an overloaded function that accepts either a user-defined lock identifier, or the lock handle returned by the ALLOCATE_UNIQUE procedure.

name: dbms_lock.request
body:
id => $1
	, lockhandle => $2
	, lockmode => X_MODE
	, timeout => MAXWAIT
	, release_on_commit => FALSE
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOCK.REQUEST(
   id                 IN  INTEGER ||
   lockhandle         IN  VARCHAR2,
   lockmode           IN  INTEGER DEFAULT X_MODE,
   timeout            IN  INTEGER DEFAULT MAXWAIT,
   release_on_commit  IN  BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE)
  RETURN INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function requests a lock with a specified mode. REQUEST is an overloaded function that accepts either a user-defined lock identifier, or the lock handle returned by the ALLOCATE_UNIQUE procedure.

name: dbms_lock.sleep
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOCK.SLEEP (
   seconds  IN NUMBER);
descriptionText: This procedure suspends the session for a specified period of time.

name: dbms_logmnr.add_logfile
descriptionText: This procedure adds a file to an existing or newly created list of log files for LogMiner to process.

name: dbms_logmnr.column_present
descriptionText: This function is designed to be used in conjunction with the MINE_VALUE function.

name: dbms_logmnr.end_logmnr
bodyFullText: DBMS_LOGMNR.END_LOGMNR;
descriptionText: This procedure finishes a LogMiner session. Because this procedure performs cleanup operations that may not otherwise be done, you must use it to properly end a LogMiner session. This procedure is called automatically when you log out of a database session or when you call DBMS_LOGMNR.ADD_LOGFILE and specify the NEW option.

name: dbms_logmnr.mine_value
descriptionText: This function facilitates queries based on a colum\'s data value. This function takes two arguments. The first one specifies whether to mine the redo (REDO_VALUE) or undo (UNDO_VALUE) portion of the data. The second argument is a string that specifies the fully qualified name of the column to be mined. The MINE_VALUE function always returns a string that can be converted back to the original datatype.

name: dbms_logmnr.remove_logfile
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGMNR.REMOVE_LOGFILE ( 
   LogFileName     IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure removes a redo log file from an existing list of redo log files for LogMiner to process.

name: dbms_logmnr.start_logmnr
body:
startScn => 0
	, endScn => 0
	, startTime => '01-jan-1988'
	, endTime => '31-dec-2110'
	, DictFileName => ''
	, Options => 0
bodyNoDefault:
startScn => $1
	, endScn => $2
	, startTime => $3
	, endTime => $4
	, DictFileName => $5
	, Options => $6
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGMNR.START_LOGMNR ( 
   startScn           IN NUMBER default 0,
   endScn             IN NUMBER default 0,
   startTime          IN DATE default '01-jan-1988',
   endTime            IN DATE default '31-dec-2110',
   DictFileName       IN VARCHAR2 default '',
   Options            IN BINARY_INTEGER default 0 );
descriptionText: This procedure starts LogMiner by loading the dictionary that LogMiner will use to translate internal schema object identifiers to names.

name: dbms_logmnr_d.build
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGMNR_D.BUILD (
     dictionary_filename  IN  VARCHAR2,
     dictionary_location  IN  VARCHAR2,
     options              IN  NUMBER);
descriptionText: This procedure extracts the LogMiner data dictionary to either the redo log files or to a flat file.

name: dbms_logmnr_d.set_tablespace
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGMNR_D.SET_TABLESPACE (
     new_tablespace        IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: By default, all LogMiner tables are created to use the SYSAUX tablespace. However, it may be desirable to have LogMiner tables use an alternate tablespace. Use this procedure to move LogMiner tables to an alternate tablespace.

name: dbms_logstdby.apply_set
descriptionText: Use this procedure to set values of parameters that configure and manage SQL Apply in a logical standby database environment. All parameters, except for PRESERVE_COMMIT_ORDER, can be changed without having to stop SQL Apply.

name: dbms_logstdby.apply_unset
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.APPLY_UNSET (
     inname          IN VARCHAR);
descriptionText: Use the APPLY_UNSET procedure to restore the default values of the parameters that you changed with the APPLY_SET procedure.

name: dbms_logstdby.build
bodyFullText: DBMS_LOGSTDBY.BUILD;
descriptionText: Use this procedure on the primary database to record relevant metadata (LogMiner dictionary) information in the redo log, which will subsequently be used by SQL Apply. This procedure will enable database-wide primary- and unique-key supplemental logging, if necessary.

name: dbms_logstdby.eds_add_table
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.EDS_ADD_TABLE (
     table_owner        IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name         IN VARCHAR2,
                             p_dblink           IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure adds EDS-based replication for the table. It should be invoked on the primary database first and then on the standby database.

name: dbms_logstdby.eds_evolve_automatic
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.EDS_EVOLVE_AUTOMATIC (
     options            IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure either enables or disables automatic DDL handling for EDS tables.

name: dbms_logstdby.eds_evolve_manual
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.EDS_EVOLVE_MANUAL (
     options            IN VARCHAR2,
     table_owner        IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name         IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure allows you to evolve EDS tables manually (that is, manually take compensating actions based on DDLs on the base tables with EDS-replication).

name: dbms_logstdby.eds_remove_table
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.EDS_REMOVE_TABLE (
     table_owner        IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name         IN VARCHAR2,
descriptionText: This procedure removes EDS-based replication for the specified table. It also drops the shadow table and triggers.

name: dbms_logstdby.instantiate_table
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.INSTANTIATE_TABLE (
     schema_name         IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name          IN VARCHAR2,
     dblink              IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure creates and populates a table in the standby database from a corresponding table in the primary database. The table requires the name of the database link (dblink) as an input parameter. If the table already exists in the logical standby database, it will be dropped and re-created based on the table definition at the primary database. This procedure only brings over the data associated with the table, and not the associated indexes and constraints.

name: dbms_logstdby.is_apply_server
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.IS_APPLY_SERVER
RETURN BOOLEAN;
descriptionText: This function returns TRUE if it is executed from PL/SQL in the context of a logical standby apply server process. This function is used in conjunction with triggers that have the fire_once parameter in the DBMS_DDL.SET_TRIGGER_FIRING_PROPERTY subprogram set to FALSE (the default is TRUE). Such triggers are executed when the relevant target is updated by an apply process. This function can be used within the body of the trigger to ensure that the trigger takes different (or no) actions on the primary or on the standby.

name: dbms_logstdby.map_primary_scn
bodyFullText: DBMS_LOGSTDBY.MAP_PRIMARY_SCN(primary_scn NUMBER) RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: Returns an SCN on the standby that predates the supplied SCN from the primary database by at least 5 minutes. This function can be used to determine a safe SCN to use in a compensating flashback database operation at the logical standby database, following a flashback database operation or a point-in-time recovery operation at the primary database.

name: dbms_logstdby.prepare_for_new_primary
descriptionText: The PREPARE_FOR_NEW_PRIMARY procedure must be invoked at a logical standby database following a failover if that standby database was not the target of the failover operation. Such a standby database must process the exact same set of redo logs processed at the new primary database. This routine ensures that the local logical standby database has not processed more redo than the new primary database and reports the set of archive logs that must be replaced to ensure consistency. The set of replacement logs will be reported in the alert.log. These logs must be copied to the logical standby and registered using the ALTER DATABASE REGISTER LOGICAL LOGFILE statement.

name: dbms_logstdby.purge_session
bodyFullText: DBMS_LOGSTDBY.PURGE_SESSION;
descriptionText: Identifies all archived redo log files that have been applied to the logical standby database and are no longer needed by SQL Apply. Once identified, you can issue operating system commands to delete some or all of the unnecessary archived redo log files.

name: dbms_logstdby.rebuild
bodyFullText: DBMS_LOGSTDBY.REBUILD;
descriptionText: This procedure is used if a database that has recently changed its role to a primary database following a failover operation fails to record relevant metadata (including the LogMiner dictionary) in the redo stream required for other logical standby databases.

name: dbms_logstdby.set_tablespace
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.SET_TABLESPACE(
           NEW_TABLESPACE IN VARCHAR2)
descriptionText: Moves metadata tables required by SQL Apply to the user-specified tablespace. By default, the metadata tables are created in the SYSAUX tablespace. SQL Apply cannot be running when you invoke this procedure.

name: dbms_logstdby.skip
body:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => NULL
	, object_name => NULL
	, proc_name => NULL
	, use_like => TRUE
	, esc => NULL
bodyNoDefault:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => $2
	, object_name => $3
	, proc_name => $4
	, use_like => $5
	, esc => $6
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.SKIP (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     proc_name                 IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     use_like                  IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
     esc                       IN CHAR1 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: The SKIP procedure can be used to define rules that will be used by SQL Apply to skip the application of certain changes to the logical standby database. For example, the SKIP procedure can be used to skip changes to a subset of tables in the logical standby database. It can also be used to specify DDL statements that should not be applied at the logical standby database or should be modified before they are applied in the logical standby database. One reason why a DDL statement may need to be modified is to accommodate a different directory structure on the logical standby database.

name: dbms_logstdby.skip_error
body:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => NULL
	, object_name => NULL
	, proc_name => NULL
	, use_like => NULL
	, esc => NULL
bodyNoDefault:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => $2
	, object_name => $3
	, proc_name => $4
	, use_like => $5
	, esc => $6
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.SKIP_ERROR (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     proc_name                 IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     use_like                  IN BOOLEAN  DEFAULT NULL,
     esc                       IN CHAR1    DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: Upon encountering an error, the logical standby database uses the criteria contained in this procedure to determine a course of action. The default action when a match is found is to skip the error and continue with applying changes. However, if a procedure is supplied, then SKIP_ERROR can take other actions depending on the situation. It can do nothing, which causes SQL Apply to stop, or it can change the error message text and stop SQL Apply, or it can actually skip the error.

name: dbms_logstdby.skip_transaction
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.SKIP_TRANSACTION (
     xidusn          IN NUMBER,
     xidslt          IN NUMBER,
     xidsqn          IN NUMBER);
descriptionText: This procedure provides a way to skip (ignore) applying transactions to the logical standby database. You can skip specific transactions by specifying transaction identification information.

name: dbms_logstdby.unskip
body:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => NULL
	, object_name => $2
	, container_name => NULL
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.UNSKIP (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFUALT NULL,
     container_name            IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: Use the UNSKIP procedure to delete rules specified earlier with the SKIP procedure. The parameters specified in the UNSKIP procedure must match exactly for it to delete an already-specified rule.

name: dbms_logstdby.unskip_error
body:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => NULL
	, object_name => NULL
	, container_name => NULL
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.UNSKIP_ERROR (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     container_name            IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: Use the UNSKIP_ERROR procedure to delete rules specified earlier with the SKIP_ERROR procedure. The parameters specified in the UNSKIP_ERROR procedure must match exactly for the procedure to delete an already-specified rule.

name: dbms_logstdby.unskip_transaction
bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.UNSKIP_TRANSACTION (
     xidusn_p         IN NUMBER,
     xidslt_p         IN NUMBER,
     xidsqn_p         IN NUMBER);
descriptionText: Use the UNSKIP_TRANSACTION procedure to delete rules specified earlier with the SKIP_TRANSACTION procedure. The parameters specified in the UNSKIP_TRANSACTION procedure must match exactly for the procedure to delete an already-specified rule.

name: dbms_logstdby_context.clear_all_context

name: dbms_metadata.open

DBMS_METADATA.OPEN (

name: dbms_metadata.openw

DBMS_METADATA.SET_COUNT (
   handle           IN NUMBER,
   value            IN NUMBER,
   object_type_path IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure specifies the maximum number of objects to be retrieved in a single FETCH_xxx call. By default, each call to FETCH_xxx returns one object. You can use the SET_COUNT procedure to override this default. If FETCH_xxx is called from a client, specifying a count value greater than 1 can result in fewer server round trips and, therefore, improved performance.

name: dbms_metadata.set_filter

DBMS_METADATA.SET_FILTER (

name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.set_proxy
descriptionText: This procedure sets the host and port of the proxy server for Internet access. This procedure must be called if the database server accesses the Internet using a proxy server. Internet access is necessary because some rules need to look up the Object Naming Service (ONS) table to get the company prefix index.

name: dbms_mgd_id_utl.validate_scheme
descriptionText: This function validates the input tag data translation XML against the Oracle Database tag data translation schema.

name: dbms_mgwadm.cleanup_gateway
descriptionText: This procedure cleans up Messaging Gateway. The procedure performs cleanup or recovery actions that may be needed when Messaging Gateway is left in some abnormal or unexpected condition. The MGW_GATEWAY view lists Messaging Gateway status and configuration information that pertains to the cleanup actions.

name: dbms_monitor.client_id_stat_disable

   client_id            IN   VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure will disable statistics accumulation for all instances and remove the accumulated results from V$CLIENT_STATS view enabled by the CLIENT_ID_STAT_ENABLE Procedure.

name: dbms_monitor.client_id_stat_enable
bodyFullText:
DBMS_MONITOR.CLIENT_ID_STAT_ENABLE(
   client_id            IN   VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure enables statistic gathering for a given Client Identifier. Statistics gathering is global for the database and persistent across instance starts and restarts. That is, statistics are enabled for all instances of the same database, including restarts. Statistics are viewable through V$CLIENT_STATS views.

name: dbms_monitor.client_id_trace_disable

 client_id    IN  VARCHAR2);

descriptionText: This procedure enables SQL trace for the whole database or a specific instance.

name: dbms_monitor.serv_mod_act_stat_disable
bodyFullText:
DBMS_MONITOR.SERV_MOD_ACT_STAT_DISABLE(
   service_name    IN VARCHAR2,
   module_name     IN VARCHAR2,
   action_name     IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT ALL_ACTIONS);
descriptionText: This procedure will disable statistics accumulation and remove the accumulated results from V$SERV_MOD_ACT_STATS view. Statistics disabling is persistent for the database. That is, service statistics are disabled for instances of the same database (plus dblinks that have been activated as a result of the enable).

name: dbms_monitor.serv_mod_act_stat_enable
bodyFullText:
DBMS_MONITOR.SERV_MOD_ACT_STAT_ENABLE(
   service_name    IN VARCHAR2,
   module_name     IN VARCHAR2,
   action_name     IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT ALL_ACTIONS);
descriptionText: This procedure enables statistic gathering for a given combination of Service Name, MODULE and ACTION. Calling this procedure enables statistic gathering for a hierarchical combination of Service name, MODULE name, and ACTION name on all instances for the same database. Statistics are accessible by means of the V$SERV_MOD_ACT_STATS view.

name: dbms_mview.begin_table_reorganization
descriptionText: This procedure performs a process to preserve materialized view data needed for refresh. It must be called before a master table is reorganized.

name: dbms_mview.end_table_reorganization
descriptionText: This procedure ensures that the materialized view data for the master table is valid and that the master table is in the proper state. It must be called after a master table is reorganized.

name: dbms_mview.estimate_mview_size
bodyFullText:
DBMS_MVIEW.ESTIMATE_MVIEW_SIZE (
   stmt_id       IN  VARCHAR2,
   select_clause IN  VARCHAR2,
   num_rows      OUT NUMBER,
   num_bytes     OUT NUMBER);
descriptionText: This procedure estimates the size of a materialized view that you might create, in bytes and number of rows.

name: dbms_mview.explain_mview
descriptionText: This procedure enables you to learn what is possible with a materialized view or potential materialized view. For example, you can determine if a materialized view is fast refreshable and what types of query rewrite you can perform with a particular materialized view.

name: dbms_mview.explain_rewrite
bodyFullText:
DBMS_MVIEW.EXPLAIN_REWRITE (
    query           VARCHAR2,
    mv              VARCHAR2(30),
    statement_id    VARCHAR2(30));
descriptionText: This procedure enables you to learn why a query failed to rewrite, or, if it rewrites, which materialized views will be used. Using the results from the procedure, you can take the appropriate action needed to make a query rewrite if at all possible. The query specified in the EXPLAIN_REWRITE statement is never actually executed.

name: dbms_mview.i_am_a_refresh
bodyFullText:
DBMS_MVIEW.I_AM_A_REFRESH
   RETURN BOOLEAN;
descriptionText: This function returns the value of the I_AM_REFRESH package state.

name: dbms_mview.pmarker
descriptionText: This function returns a partition marker from a rowid. It is used for Partition Change Tracking (PCT).

name: dbms_mview.purge_direct_load_log
bodyFullText: DBMS_MVIEW.PURGE_DIRECT_LOAD_LOG();
descriptionText: This procedure removes entries from the direct loader log after they are no longer needed for any known materialized view. This procedure usually is used in environments using Oracl\'s data warehousing technology.

name: dbms_mview.purge_log
bodyFullText:
DBMS_MVIEW.PURGE_LOG (
   master        IN   VARCHAR2,
   num           IN   BINARY_INTEGER := 1,
   flag          IN   VARCHAR2       := 'NOP');
descriptionText: This procedure purges rows from the materialized view log.

name: dbms_mview.purge_mview_from_log
descriptionText: This procedure is called on the master site or master materialized view site to delete the rows in materialized view refresh related data dictionary tables maintained at the master for the specified materialized view identified by mview_id or the combination of mviewowner, mviewname, and mviewsite. If the materialized view specified is the oldest materialized view to have refreshed from any of the master tables or master materialized views, then the materialized view log is also purged. This procedure does not unregister the materialized view.

name: dbms_network_acl_utility.contains_host
bodyFullText:
DBMS_NETWORK_ACL_UTILITY.CONTAINS_HOST (
   host      IN    VARCHAR2,
   domain    IN    VARCHAR2)
 RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function determines if the given host is equal to or contained in the given host, domain, or subnet. It handles different representation of the same IP address or subnet. For example, an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address is considered equal to the IPv4-native address it represents. It does not perform domain name resolution when evaluating the host or domain.

name: dbms_network_acl_utility.domain_level
descriptionText: This function returns the domain level of the given host name, domain, or subnet.

name: dbms_network_acl_utility.domains
descriptionText: For a given host, this function returns the domains whose ACL assigned determines if a user has the privilege to access the given host or not. When the IP address of the host is given, return the subnets instead.

name: dbms_network_acl_utility.equals_host
bodyFullText:
DBMS_NETWORK_ACL_UTILITY.EQUALS_HOST (
   host1    IN    VARCHAR2,
   host2    IN    VARCHAR2)
 RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function determines if the two given hosts, domains, or subnets are equal. It handles different representation of the same IP address or subnet. For example, an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address is considered equal to the IPv4- native address it represents. It does not perform domain name resolution when comparing the two hosts or domains.

name: dbms_odci.estimate_cpu_units
descriptionText: This function returns the approximate number of CPU instructions (in thousands) corresponding to a specified time interval (in seconds). This information can be used to associate the CPU cost with a user-defined function for the extensible optimizer.

name: dbms_offline_og.begin_instantiation
bodyFullText:
DBMS_OFFLINE_OG.BEGIN_INSTANTIATION (
   gname     IN   VARCHAR2,
   new_site  IN   VARCHAR2
   fname     IN   VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure starts offline instantiation of a master group. You must call this procedure from the master definition site.

name: dbms_offline_og.begin_load
descriptionText: This procedure disables triggers while data is imported to the new master site as part of offline instantiation. You must call this procedure from the new master site.

name: dbms_offline_og.end_instantiation
descriptionText: This procedure completes offline instantiation of a master group. You must call this procedure from the master definition site.

name: dbms_offline_og.end_load
bodyFullText:
DBMS_OFFLINE_OG.END_LOAD (
   gname     IN   VARCHAR2,
   new_site  IN   VARCHAR2
   fname     IN   VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure reenables triggers after importing data to new master site as part of offline instantiation. You must call this procedure from the new master site.

name: dbms_offline_og.resume_subset_of_masters
bodyFullText:
DBMS_OFFLINE_OG.RESUME_SUBSET_OF_MASTERS (
   gname     IN  VARCHAR2,
   new_site  IN  VARCHAR2
   override  IN  BOOLEAN := FALSE);
descriptionText: When you add a new master site to a master group by performing an offline instantiation of a master site, it might take some time to complete the offline instantiation process. This procedure resumes replication activity at all existing sites, except the new site, during offline instantiation of a master group. You typically execute this procedure after executing the DBMS_OFFLINE_OG.BEGIN_INSTANTIATION procedure. You must call this procedure from the master definition site.

name: dbms_outln.clear_used

DBMS_OUTLN.DROP_BY_CAT (

descriptionText: This procedure drops outlines that belong to a particular category. While outlines are put into the DEFAULT category unless otherwise specified, users have the option of grouping their outlines into groups called categories.

name: dbms_outln.drop_unused

descriptionText: This procedure drops outlines that have never been applied in the compilation of a SQL statement.

name: dbms_outln.exact_text_signatures

descriptionText: This procedure updates outline signatures to those that compute based on exact text matching.

name: dbms_outln.update_by_cat

name: dbms_outln.update_signatures

descriptionText: This procedure updates outline signatures to the current versio\'s signature.

name: dbms_output.disable
bodyFullText: DBMS_OUTPUT.DISABLE;
descriptionText: This procedure disables calls to PUT, PUT_LINE, NEW_LINE, GET_LINE, and GET_LINES, and purges the buffer of any remaining information.

name: dbms_output.enable
bodyFullText:
DBMS_OUTPUT.ENABLE (
   buffer_size IN INTEGER DEFAULT 20000);
descriptionText: This procedure enables calls to PUT, PUT_LINE, NEW_LINE, GET_LINE, and GET_LINES. Calls to these procedures are ignored if the DBMS_OUTPUT package is not activated.

name: dbms_output.get_line
descriptionText: This procedure retrieves a single line of buffered information.

name: dbms_output.get_lines
descriptionText: This procedure retrieves an array of lines from the buffer.

name: dbms_output.new_line
bodyFullText: DBMS_OUTPUT.NEW_LINE;
descriptionText: This procedure puts an end-of-line marker. The GET_LINE Procedure and the GET_LINES Procedure return "lines" as delimited by "newlines". Every call to the PUT_LINE Procedure or NEW_LINE Procedure generates a line that is returned by GET_LINE(S).

name: dbms_output.put
bodyFullText:
DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT (
    item IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure places a partial line in the buffer.

name: dbms_output.put_line
bodyFullText:
DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE (
   item IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure places a line in the buffer.

name: dbms_parallel_execute.adm_drop_chunks
descriptionText: This procedure drops all chunks of the specified task owned by the specified owner.

name: dbms_parallel_execute.adm_drop_task
descriptionText: This procedure drops the task of the specified user and all related chunks.

name: dbms_parallel_execute.adm_stop_task
descriptionText: This procedure stops the task of the specified owner and related job slaves.

name: dbms_parallel_execute.adm_task_status
bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.ADM_TASK_STATUS  (
   task_owner      IN  VARCHAR2,
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2)
 RETURN NUMBER;

name: dbms_parallel_execute.create_chunks_by_number_col
bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_NUMBER_COL (
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_owner     IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_name      IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_column    IN  VARCHAR2,
   chunk_size      IN  NUMBER);
descriptionText: This procedure chunks the table (associated with the specified task) by the specified column. The specified column must be a NUMBER column. This procedure takes the MIN and MAX value of the column, and then divides the range evenly according to chunk_size. The chunks are:

name: dbms_parallel_execute.create_chunks_by_rowid
bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_ROWID (
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_owner     IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_name      IN  VARCHAR2,
   by_row          IN  BOOLEAN,
   chunk_size      IN  NUMBER);
descriptionText: This procedure chunks the table (associated with the specified task) by ROWID. num_row and num_block are approximate guidance for the size of each chunk. The table to be chunked must be a physical table with physical ROWID having views and table functions. Index-organized tables are not allowed.

name: dbms_parallel_execute.create_chunks_by_sql
bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.CREATE_CHUNKS_BY_SQL (
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   sql_statement   IN  CLOB,
   by_rowid        IN  BOOLEAN);
descriptionText: This procedure chunks the table (associated with the specified task) by means of a user-provided SELECT statement. The SELECT statement that returns the range of each chunk must have two columns: start_id and end_id. If the task is to chunk by ROWID, then the two columns must be of ROWID type. If the task is to chunk the table by NUMBER column, then the two columns must be of NUMBER type. The procedure provides the flexibility to users who want to deploy user-defined chunk algorithms.

name: dbms_parallel_execute.create_task
descriptionText: This procedure creates a task for the current user. The pairing of task_name and current_user must be unique.

name: dbms_parallel_execute.drop_chunks
bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.DROP_CHUNKS (
   task_name       IN VARCHAR2);

name: dbms_parallel_execute.drop_task
bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.DROP_TASK (
   task_name       IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure drops the task and all related chunks.

name: dbms_parallel_execute.generate_task_name
descriptionText: This function returns a unique name for a task. The name is of the form prefixN where N is a number from a sequence. If no prefix is specified, the generated name is, by default, TASK$_1, TASK$_2, TASK$_3, and so on. If\'SCOT\' is specified as the prefix, the name is SCOTT1, SCOTT2, and so on.

name: dbms_parallel_execute.get_number_col_chunk
bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.GET_NUMBER_COL_CHUNK (
   task_name       IN VARCHAR2,
   chunk_id        OUT NUMBER,
   start_rowid     OUT ROWID,      
   end_id          OUT ROWID,
   any_rows        OUT BOOLEAN);
descriptionText: This procedure picks an unassigned NUMBER chunk and changes it to ASSIGNED. If there are no more chunks to assign, any_rows is set to FALSE. Otherwise, the chunk_id, start, and end_id of the chunk are returned as OUT parameters. The chunk info in DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE_CHUNKS$ is updated as follows: STATUS becomes ASSIGNED; START_TIMESTAMP records the current time; END_TIMESTAMP is cleared.

name: dbms_parallel_execute.get_rowid_chunk
bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.GET_ROWID_CHUNK (
   task_name       IN VARCHAR2,
   chunk_id        OUT NUMBER,
   start_rowid     OUT ROWID,      
   end_id          OUT ROWID,
   any_rows        OUT BOOLEAN);
descriptionText: This procedure picks an unassigned ROWID chunk and changes it to ASSIGNED. If there are no more chunks to assign, any_rows is set to FALSE. Otherwise, the chunk_id, start, and end_id of the chunk are returned as OUT parameters. The chunk info in DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE_CHUNKS$ is updated as follows: STATUS becomes ASSIGNED; START_TIMESTAMP records the current time; END_TIMESTAMP is cleared.

	, sql_stmt => $2
	, language_flag => $3

	, fire_apply_trigger => TRUE

	, job_class => $8
	, force => $9
bodyFullText:
DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.RESUME_TASK (
   task_name                     IN  VARCHAR2,
   sql_stmt                      IN  CLOB,   
   language_flag                 IN  NUMBER,
   edition                       IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   apply_crossedition_trigger    IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   fire_apply_trigger            IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT TRUE,
   parallel_level                IN  NUMBER    DEFAULT 0,
   job_class                     IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT 'DEFAULT_JOB_CLASS',
   force                         IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE);

DBMS_PARALLEL_EXECUTE.RESUME_TASK (
   task_name                     IN  VARCHAR2,
   force                         IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE);
descriptionText: This procedure retries the specified the task if the RUN_TASK Procedure finished with an error, or resumes the task if a crash occurred. You can only invoke this procedure if the task is in a CRASHED or FINISHED_WITH_ERROR state. For a crashed serial execution, the state remains in processing. The FORCE option allows you to resume any task in PROCESSING state. However, it is your responsibility to determine that a crash has occurred. The procedure resumes processing the chunks which have not been processed. Also, chunks which are in PROCESSED_WITH_ERROR or ASSIGNED (due to crash) state are processed because those chunks did not commit. This procedure takes the same argument as the RUN_TASK Procedure. The overload which takes task_name as the only input argument re-uses the arguments provided in the previous invoking of the RUN_TASK Procedure or RESUME_TASK Procedures.

   language_flag                 IN  NUMBER,

   apply_crossedition_trigger    IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   fire_apply_trigger            IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT TRUE,
   parallel_level                IN  NUMBER    DEFAULT 0,
   job_class                     IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT 'DEFAULT_JOB_CLASS');
descriptionText: This procedure executes the specified statement (sql_stmt) on the chunks in parallel. It commits after processing each chunk. The specified statement must have two placeholders called start_id and end_id, respectively, which represent the range of the chunk to be processed. The type of each placeholder must be ROWID where ROWID-based chunking was used, or NUMBER where NUMBER-based chunking was used.

name: dbms_part.cleanup_gidx
descriptionText: As a consequence of prior partition maintenance operations with asynchronous global index maintenance, global indexes can contain entries pointing to data segments that no longer exist. These stale index rows will not cause any correctness issues or corruptions during any operation on the table or index, whether these are queries, DMLs, DDLs or analyze. This procedure will identify and cleanup these global indexes to ensure efficiency in terms of storage and performance.

   schema_name       IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   table_name        IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL, 
   partition_name    IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: There are many possible points of failure when performing ALTER TABLE ... MOVE PARTITION ... ONLINE operations. This procedure pro-actively cleans up such failed online move operations instead of waiting for the background process (SMON) to do so.

This XML file can then be used to plug the pluggable database into a multitenant container database (CDB) using CREATE PLUGGABLE DATABASE statement.This procedure is intended for cases when an XML file describing a pluggable database is corrupted or lost.

name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_data
descriptionText: This function provides top level patch information for the patch (such as Patch ID, patch creation time) in the XML element.

name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_files
descriptionText: This function provides the list of files modified in the given patch number in XML format.

name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_install_info
bodyFullText:
DBMS_QOPATCH.GET_OPATCH_INSTALL_INFO
 RETURNS XMLTYPE;
descriptionText: This function returns the XML element containing the ORACLE_HOME details such as patch and inventory location.

name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_list
bodyFullText:
DBMS_QOPATCH.GET_OPATCH_LIST
 RETURN XMLTYPE;
descriptionText: This function provides list of patches installed as an XML element from the XML inventory.

name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_lsinventory
bodyFullText:
DBMS_QOPATCH.GET_OPATCH_LSINVENTORY
 RETURN XMLTYPE;
descriptionText: This function returns whole opatch inventory as XML instance document.

name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_olays
descriptionText: This function provides overlay patches for a given patch as XML element.

name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_preqs
descriptionText: This function provides prerequisite patches for a given patch as XML element.

name: dbms_qopatch.get_opatch_xslt
bodyFullText:
DBMS_QOPATCH.GET_OPATCH_XSLT
 RETURN XMLTYPE;
descriptionText: This function returns the style-sheet for the opatch XML inventory presentation. You can use the return type of this subprogram to perform XMLTRANSFORM and the transformed result has the same appearance as opatch text output.

name: dbms_qopatch.get_pending_activity
bodyFullText:
DBMS_QOPATCH.GET_PENDING_ACTIVITY
 RETURN XMLTYPE;
descriptionText: This function returns the information related to SQL patches applied on a single instance by querying the binary inventory. If this is Oracle Real Application Clusters (RAC) system, it will list the node names where the SQL patch is not applied.

name: dbms_qopatch.get_sqlpatch_status
bodyFullText:
DBMS_QOPATCH.GET_SQLPATCH_STATUS (
   patchnum IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure displays the SQL patch status by querying from SQL patch registry to produce complete patch level information. If the patch number is given, it displays the information specific to the given SQL patch, otherwise information for all SQL patches.

name: dbms_qopatch.is_patch_installed
descriptionText: This function provides information (such as patchID, application date, and SQL patch information) on the installed patch as XML node by querying the XML inventory.

name: dbms_qopatch.patch_conflict_detection
descriptionText: This function returns the conflicting patch for a given file, if it conflicts with an existing patch.

name: dbms_qopatch.set_current_opinst
descriptionText: This procedure sets the node name and instance to get the inventory details specific to it in an Oracle Real Application Clusters (RAC) environment.

name: dbms_random.initialize
bodyFullText:
DBMS_RANDOM.INITIALIZE (
   val  IN  BINARY_INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure initializes the generator.

name: dbms_random.normal
bodyFullText:
DBMS_RANDOM.NORMAL
  RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function returns random numbers in a standard normal distribution.

name: dbms_random.random
bodyFullText:
DBMS_RANDOM.RANDOM
   RETURN binary_integer;
descriptionText: This procedure generates a random number.

name: dbms_random.seed
descriptionText: This procedure resets the seed.

name: dbms_random.string
bodyFullText:
DBMS_RANDOM.STRING
   opt  IN  CHAR,
   len  IN  NUMBER)
  RETURN VARCHAR2;
descriptionText: This function gets a random string.

name: dbms_random.terminate
bodyFullText: DBMS_RANDOM.TERMINATE;
descriptionText: When you are finished with the package, call the TERMINATE procedure.

name: dbms_random.value
descriptionText: The basic function gets a random number, greater than or equal to 0 and less than 1, with 38 digits to the right of the decimal (38-digit precision). Alternatively, you can get a random Oracle number x, where x is greater than or equal to low and less than high.

name: dbms_redefinition.abort_redef_table
bodyFullText:
DBMS_REDEFINITION.ABORT_REDEF_TABLE (
   uname                   IN  VARCHAR2,
   orig_table              IN  VARCHAR2,
   int_table               IN  VARCHAR2,
   part_name               IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure cleans up errors that occur during the redefinition process. This procedure can also be used to terminate the redefinition process any time after the START_REDEF_TABLE Procedure has been called and before the FINISH_REDEF_TABLE Procedure is called. This process will remove the temporary objects that are created by the redefinition process such as materialized view logs.

name: dbms_redefinition.can_redef_table
bodyFullText:
DBMS_REDEFINITION.CAN_REDEF_TABLE (
   uname         IN  VARCHAR2,
   tname        IN  VARCHAR2,
   options_flag  IN  PLS_INTEGER := 1,
   part_name     IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure determines if a given table can be redefined online. This is the first step of the online redefinition process. If the table is not a candidate for online redefinition, an error message is raised.

   uname                    IN  VARCHAR2,

   int_table                IN  VARCHAR2,
   copy_indexes             IN  PLS_INTEGER := 1,
   copy_triggers            IN  BOOLEAN     := TRUE,
   copy_constraints         IN  BOOLEAN     := TRUE,
   copy_privileges          IN  BOOLEAN     := TRUE,
   ignore_errors            IN  BOOLEAN     := FALSE,

   copy_statistics          IN  BOOLEAN     := FALSE, 
   copy_mvlog               IN  BOOLEAN     := FALSE);
descriptionText: This procedure clones the dependent objects of the table being redefined onto the interim table and registers the dependent objects. This procedure does not clone the already registered dependent objects.

name: dbms_redefinition.finish_redef_table
body:
uname => $1
	, orig_table => $2
	, int_table => $3
	, part_name => NULL
	, dml_lock_timeout => NULL
	, continue_after_errors => FALSE
bodyNoDefault:
uname => $1
	, orig_table => $2
	, int_table => $3
	, part_name => $4
	, dml_lock_timeout => $5
	, continue_after_errors => $6
bodyFullText:
DBMS_REDEFINITION.FINISH_REDEF_TABLE (
   uname                   IN   VARCHAR2,
   orig_table              IN   VARCHAR2,
   int_table               IN   VARCHAR2,
   part_name               IN   VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   dml_lock_timeout        IN   PLS_INTEGER := NULL,
   continue_after_errors   IN   BOOLEAN := FALSE);
descriptionText: This procedure completes the redefinition process. Before this step, you can create new indexes, triggers, grants, and constraints on the interim table. The referential constraints involving the interim table must be disabled. After completing this step, the original table is redefined with the attributes and data of the interim table. The original table is locked briefly during this procedure.

	, lob_tablespace => $8
	, lob_store_as => $9
bodyFullText:
DBMS_REDEFINITION.REDEF_TABLE (
   uname                       IN  VARCHAR2,
   tname                       IN  VARCHAR2,    
   table_compression_type      IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL, 
   table_part_tablespace       IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL, 
   index_key_compression_type  IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   index_tablespace            IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   lob_compression_type        IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   lob_tablespace              IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   lob_store_as                IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure provides a single interface that integrates several redefinition steps including the CAN_REDEF_TABLE Procedure, the START_REDEF_TABLE Procedure, the COPY_TABLE_DEPENDENTS Procedure and the FINISH_REDEF_TABLE Procedure. This procedure can change data storage properties including tablespaces (for table, partition, subpartition, index, LOB column), compress type (for table, partition, subpartition, index, LOB column) and STORE_AS clause for the LOB column.

   interval              IN    VARCHAR2,
   implicit_destroy      IN    BOOLEAN         := FALSE,

   parallelism           IN    BINARY_INTEGER  := NULL,
   heap_size             IN    BINARY_INTEGER  := NULL);

	, comment => ''
