name: DBMS_SCHEDULER.repeat_interval
bodyFullText:
repeat_interval = regular_schedule | combined_schedule
 
regular_schedule = frequency_clause
[";" interval_clause] [";" bymonth_clause] [";" byweekno_clause]
[";" byyearday_clause] [";" bydate_clause] [";" bymonthday_clause]
[";" byday_clause] [";" byhour_clause] [";" byminute_clause]
[";" bysecond_clause] [";" bysetpos_clause] [";" include_clause]
[";" exclude_clause] [";" intersect_clause][";" periods_clause]
[";" byperiod_clause]
 
frequency_clause = "FREQ" "=" ( predefined_frequency | user_defined_frequency )
predefined_frequency = "YEARLY" | "MONTHLY" | "WEEKLY" | "DAILY" | 
   "HOURLY" | "MINUTELY" | "SECONDLY"
user_defined_frequency = named_schedule

interval_clause = "INTERVAL" "=" intervalnum
   intervalnum = 1 through 99
bymonth_clause = "BYMONTH" "=" monthlist
   monthlist = month ( "," month)*
   month = numeric_month | char_month
   numeric_month = 1 | 2 | 3 ...  12
   char_month = "JAN" | "FEB" | "MAR" | "APR" | "MAY" | "JUN" |
   "JUL" | "AUG" | "SEP" | "OCT" | "NOV" | "DEC"
byweekno_clause = "BYWEEKNO" "=" weeknumber_list
   weeknumber_list = weeknumber ( "," weeknumber)*
   weeknumber = [minus] weekno
   weekno = 1 through 53
byyearday_clause = "BYYEARDAY" "=" yearday_list
   yearday_list = yearday ( "," yearday)*
   yearday = [minus] yeardaynum
   yeardaynum = 1 through 366
bydate_clause = "BYDATE" "=" date_list
   date_list = date ( "," date)*
   date = [YYYY]MMDD [ offset | span ]
bymonthday_clause = "BYMONTHDAY" "=" monthday_list
   monthday_list = monthday ( "," monthday)*
   monthday = [minus] monthdaynum
   monthdaynum = 1 through 31
byday_clause = "BYDAY" "=" byday_list
   byday_list = byday ( "," byday)*
   byday = [weekdaynum] day
   weekdaynum = [minus] daynum
   daynum = 1 through 53 /* if frequency is yearly */
   daynum = 1 through 5  /* if frequency is monthly */
   day = "MON" | "TUE" | "WED" | "THU" | "FRI" | "SAT" | "SUN"
BYTIME clause:  BYTIME=[hour_minute_second_list|minute_second_list]
   hour_minute_second_list: hh24mmss, .., hh24mmss
   minute_second_list: mmss, .. mmss
byhour_clause = "BYHOUR" "=" hour_list
   hour_list = hour ( "," hour)*
   hour = 0 through 23
byminute_clause = "BYMINUTE" "=" minute_list
   minute_list = minute ( "," minute)*
   minute = 0 through 59
bysecond_clause = "BYSECOND" "=" second_list
   second_list = second ( "," second)*
   second = 0 through 59
bysetpos_clause = "BYSETPOS" "=" setpos_list
   setpos_list = setpos ("," setpos)*
   setpos = [minus] setpos_num
   setpos_num = 1 through 9999

include_clause = "INCLUDE" "=" schedule_list
exclude_clause = "EXCLUDE" "=" schedule_list
intersect_clause = "INTERSECT" "=" schedule_list
schedule_list = schedule_clause ("," schedule_clause)*
schedule_clause = named_schedule [ offset ]
named_schedule = [schema "."] schedule
periods_clause = "PERIODS" "=" periodnum
byperiod_clause = "BYPERIOD" "=" period_list
period_list = periodnum ("," periodnum)*
periodnum = 1 through 100

offset = ("+" | "-") ["OFFSET:"] duration_val
span = ("+" | "-" | "^") "SPAN:" duration_val
duration_val = dur-weeks | dur_days
dur_weeks = numofweeks "W"
dur_days = numofdays "D"
numofweeks = 1 through 53
numofdays = 1 through 376
minus = "-"

combined_schedule = schedule_list
descriptionText: The Scheduler uses a rich calendaring syntax to enable you to define repeating schedules, such as "every Tuesday and Friday at 4:00 p.m." or "the second Wednesday of every month." This calendaring syntax is used in calendaring expressions in the repeat_interval argument of a number of package subprograms. Evaluating a calendaring expression results in a set of discrete timestamps.

name: dbms_scheduler.reset_job_argument_value
descriptionText: This procedure resets (clears) the value previously set to an argument for a job.

name: dbms_scheduler.run_chain
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.RUN_CHAIN (
   chain_name                IN VARCHAR2,
   start_steps               IN VARCHAR2,
   job_name                  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure immediately runs a chain or part of a chain by creating a run-once job with the job name given. If no job_name is given, one is generated of the form RUN_CHAIN$_chainnameN, where chainname is the first 8 characters of the chain name and N is an integer.If a list of start steps is given, only those steps are started when the chain begins running. Steps not in the list that would normally have started are skipped and paused (so that they or the steps after them do not run). If start_steps is NULL, then the chain starts normally—that is, it performs an initial evaluation to see which steps to start running).

name: dbms_scheduler.run_job
descriptionText: This procedure runs a job immediately.

name: dbms_scheduler.set_agent_registration_pass

   max_uses                IN NUMBER DEFAULT NULL);

The attributes that can be set depend on the object being altered. All object attributes can be changed, except the object name.

name: dbms_scheduler.set_attribute_null

If the object is enabled, it is disabled before being altered and reenabled afterward. If the object cannot be reenabled, an error is generated and the object is left in a disabled state.

NULL is a valid assignment for a program argument. The argument can be specified by position or by name. You can specify by name only when:

name: dbms_scheduler.stop_job
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.STOP_JOB (
   job_name         IN VARCHAR2
   force            IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE
   commit_semantics IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'STOP_ON_FIRST_ERROR');
descriptionText: This procedure stops currently running jobs or all jobs in a job class. After stopping the job, the state of a one-time job is set to STOPPED, whereas the state of a repeating job is set to SCHEDULED or COMPLETED, depending on whether the next run of the job is scheduled.

name: DBMS_SCHEDULER.true
bodyFullText:
TRUE
FALSE
stepname [NOT] SUCCEEDED 
stepname [NOT] FAILED 
stepname [NOT] STOPPED 
stepname [NOT] COMPLETED 
stepname ERROR_CODE IN (integer, integer, integer ...)
stepname ERROR_CODE NOT IN (integer, integer, integer ...)
stepname ERROR_CODE = integer

stepname ERROR_CODE <= integer
descriptionText: This procedure adds a new rule to an existing chain, specified as a condition-action pair. name: dbms_shared_pool.keep
descriptionText: This procedure keeps an object in the shared pool. Once an object has been kept in the shared pool, it is not subject to aging out of the pool. This may be useful for frequently used large objects. When large objects are brought into the shared pool, several objects may need to be aged out to create a contiguous area large enough.

name: dbms_shared_pool.markhot
descriptionText: This procedure marks a library cache object as a hot object.

name: dbms_shared_pool.purge
descriptionText: This procedure purges the named object or specified heap(s) of the object.

name: dbms_shared_pool.sizes
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SHARED_POOL.SIZES ( 
   minsize NUMBER);
descriptionText: This procedure shows objects in the shared_pool that are larger than the specified size. The name of the object is also given, which can be used as an argument to either the KEEP or UNKEEP calls.

name: dbms_shared_pool.unkeep
descriptionText: This procedure unkeeps the named object.

name: dbms_shared_pool.unmarkhot
descriptionText: This procedure unmarks a library cache object as a hot object.

name: dbms_space.asa_recommendations
body:
all_runs => := TRUE
	, show_manual => := TRUE
	, show_findings => := FALSE
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE.ASA_RECOMMENDATIONS (
   all_runs        IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT := TRUE,
   show_manual     IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT := TRUE,
   show_findings   IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT := FALSE)
 RETURN ASA_RECO_ROW_TB PIPELINED;
descriptionText: This function returns recommendations using the stored results of the auto segment advisor. This function returns results from the latest run on any given object.

name: dbms_space.create_index_cost
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE.CREATE_INDEX_COST (
   ddl             IN    VARCHAR2,
   used_bytes      OUT   NUMBER,
   alloc_bytes     OUT   NUMBER,
   plan_table      IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure determines the cost of creating an index on an existing table. The input is the DDL statement that will be used to create the index. The procedure will output the storage required to create the index.

name: dbms_space.create_table_cost
body:
tablespace_name => $1
	, avg_row_size => $2
	, row_count => $3
	, pct_free => $4
	, used_bytes => $5
	, alloc_bytes => $6
bodyNoDefault:
tablespace_name => $1
	, avg_row_size => $2
	, row_count => $3
	, pct_free => $4
	, used_bytes => $5
	, alloc_bytes => $6
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE.CREATE_TABLE_COST (
   tablespace_name    IN VARCHAR2,
   avg_row_size       IN NUMBER,
   row_count          IN NUMBER,
   pct_free           IN NUMBER,
   used_bytes         OUT NUMBER,
   alloc_bytes        OUT NUMBER);

DBMS_SPACE.CREATE_TABLE_COST (
   tablespace_name    IN VARCHAR2,
   colinfos           IN CREATE_TABLE_COST_COLUMNS,
   row_count          IN NUMBER,
   pct_free           IN NUMBER,
   used_bytes         OUT NUMBER,
   alloc_bytes        OUT NUMBER);

CREATE TYPE create_table_cost_colinfo IS OBJECT (
   COL_TYPE   VARCHAR(200),
   COL_SIZE   NUMBER);
descriptionText: This procedure is used in capacity planning to determine the size of the table given various attributes. The size of the object can vary widely based on the tablespace storage attributes, tablespace block size, and so on. There are two overloads of this procedure.

name: dbms_space.isdatafiledroppable_name
descriptionText: This procedure checks whether a datafile is droppable. This procedure may be called before actually dropping the file.

   objname     IN     VARCHAR2,
   partname    IN     VARCHAR2,
   objtype     IN     NUMBER) 
  RETURN dependent_segments_table PIPELINED;
descriptionText: This table function, given an object, returns the list of segments that are associated with the object.

name: dbms_space.object_growth_trend
body:
object_owner => $1
	, object_name => $2
	, object_type => $3
	, partition_name => NULL
	, start_time => NULL
	, end_time => NULL
	, interval => NULL
	, skip_interpolated => 'FALSE'
	, timeout_seconds => NULL
	, single_datapoint_flag => 'TRUE'
bodyNoDefault:
object_owner => $1
	, object_name => $2
	, object_type => $3
	, partition_name => $4
	, start_time => $5
	, end_time => $6
	, interval => $7
	, skip_interpolated => $8
	, timeout_seconds => $9
	, single_datapoint_flag => $10
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE.OBJECT_GROWTH_TREND (
   object_owner           IN    VARCHAR2,
   object_name            IN    VARCHAR2,
   object_type            IN    VARCHAR2,
   partition_name         IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   start_time             IN    TIMESTAMP DEFAULT NULL,
   end_time               IN    TIMESTAMP DEFAULT NULL,
   interval               IN    DSINTERVAL_UNCONSTRAINED DEFAULT NULL,
   skip_interpolated      IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'FALSE',
   timeout_seconds        IN    NUMBER DEFAULT NULL,
   single_datapoint_flag  IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'TRUE') 
 RETURN object_growth_trend_table PIPELINED;
descriptionText: This is a table function. The output will be in the form of one or more rows where each row describes the space usage of the object at a specific point in time. Either the space usage totals will be retrieved from Automatic Workload Repository Facilities (AWRF), or the current space usage will be computed and combined with space usage deltas retrieved from AWRF.

	, partition_name => NULL
bodyNoDefault:
segment_owner => $1
	, segment_name => $2
	, segment_type => $3
	, unformatted_blocks => $4
	, unformatted_bytes => $5
	, fs1_blocks => $6
	, fs1_bytes => $7
	, fs2_blocks => $8
	, fs2_bytes => $9
	, fs3_blocks => $10
	, fs3_bytes => $11
	, fs4_blocks => $12
	, fs4_bytes => $13
	, full_blocks => $14
	, full_bytes => $15
	, partition_name => $16
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE.SPACE_USAGE(
   segment_owner           IN  VARCHAR2,
   segment_name            IN  VARCHAR2,
   segment_type            IN  VARCHAR2,
   unformatted_blocks      OUT NUMBER,
   unformatted_bytes       OUT NUMBER,
   fs1_blocks              OUT NUMBER,
   fs1_bytes               OUT NUMBER,
   fs2_blocks              OUT NUMBER,
   fs2_bytes               OUT NUMBER,
   fs3_blocks              OUT NUMBER,
   fs3_bytes               OUT NUMBER,
   fs4_blocks              OUT NUMBER,
   fs4_bytes               OUT NUMBER,
   full_blocks             OUT NUMBER,
   full_bytes              OUT NUMBER,
   partition_name          IN  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL); 
DBMS_SPACE.SPACE_USAGE(
   segment_owner           IN    VARCHAR2,
   segment_name            IN    VARCHAR2,
   segment_type            IN    VARCHAR2,
   segment_size_blocks     OUT   NUMBER,
   segment_size_bytes      OUT   NUMBER,
   used_blocks             OUT   NUMBER,
   used_bytes              OUT   NUMBER,
   expired_blocks          OUT   NUMBER,
   expired_bytes           OUT   NUMBER,
   unexpired_blocks        OUT   NUMBER,
   unexpired_bytes         OUT   NUMBER,
   partition_name          IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: The first form of the procedure shows the space usage of data blocks under the segment High Water Mark. You can calculate usage for LOBs, LOB PARTITIONS and LOB SUBPARTITIONS. This procedure can only be used on tablespaces that are created with auto segment space management. The bitmap blocks, segment header, and extent map blocks are not accounted for by this procedure. Note that this overload cannot be used on SECUREFILE LOBs.

name: dbms_space_admin.assm_segment_verify
body:
segment_owner => $1
	, segment_name => $2
	, segment_type => $3
	, partition_name => $4
	, verify_option => SEGMENT_VERIFY_BASIC
	, attrib => NULL

segment_owner => $1
	, segment_name => $2

   segment_owner   IN VARCHAR2,
   segment_name    IN VARCHAR2,
   segment_type    IN VARCHAR2,
   partition_name  IN VARCHAR2,

name: dbms_space_admin.segment_corrupt
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.SEGMENT_CORRUPT (
   tablespace_name         IN    VARCHAR2,
   header_relative_file    IN    POSITIVE,

   corrupt_option          IN    POSITIVE  DEFAULT SEGMENT_MARK_CORRUPT);
descriptionText: This procedure marks the segment corrupt or valid so that appropriate error recovery can be done. It cannot be used on the SYSTEM tablespace.

name: dbms_space_admin.segment_drop_corrupt
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.SEGMENT_DROP_CORRUPT (
   tablespace_name         IN    VARCHAR2,
   header_relative_file    IN    POSITIVE,
   header_block            IN    POSITIVE);
descriptionText: This procedure drops a segment currently marked corrupt (without reclaiming space). For this to work, the segment must be marked temporary. To mark a corrupt segment as temporary, issue a DROP command on the segment.

bodyFullText:

name: dbms_space_admin.segment_verify
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.SEGMENT_VERIFY (

descriptionText: This procedure checks the consistency of the segment extent map with the tablespace file bitmaps.

name: dbms_space_admin.tablespace_fix_bitmaps
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.TABLESPACE_FIX_BITMAPS (
   tablespace_name         IN    VARCHAR2,
   dbarange_relative_file  IN    POSITIVE,
   dbarange_begin_block    IN    POSITIVE,

descriptionText: This procedure marks the appropriate block range (extent) as free or used in bitmap. It cannot be used on the SYSTEM tablespace.

name: dbms_space_admin.tablespace_fix_segment_states
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.TABLESPACE_FIX_SEGMENT_STATES (
   tablespace_name     IN    VARCHAR);
descriptionText: This procedure fixes the state of the segments in a tablespace in which migration was aborted. During tablespace migration to or from local, the segments are put in a transient state. If migration is aborted, then the segment states are corrected by SMON when event 10906 is set. A database with segments in such a transient state cannot be downgraded. The procedure can be used to fix the state of such segments.

name: dbms_space_admin.tablespace_migrate_from_local
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.TABLESPACE_MIGRATE_FROM_LOCAL (
   tablespace_name         IN    VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure migrates a locally managed tablespace to a dictionary-managed tablespace.

name: dbms_space_admin.tablespace_migrate_to_local
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.TABLESPACE_MIGRATE_TO_LOCAL (
   tablespace_name     IN     VARCHAR2,
   unit_size           IN     POSITIVE DEFAULT NULL,
   rfno                IN     POSITIVE DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure migrates the tablespace from a dictionary-managed format to a locally managed format. Tablespaces migrated to locally managed format are user managed.

name: dbms_space_admin.tablespace_rebuild_bitmaps

DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.TABLESPACE_REBUILD_QUOTAS (

name: dbms_space_admin.tablespace_verify

descriptionText: This procedure allows for manual flushing of the SQL plan directives that are automatically recorded in SGA memory while executing SQL statements. The information recorded in the SGA is periodically flushed by an Oracle background process. This procedure provides a way to flush the information manually.

name: dbms_spd.get_prefs

name: dbms_spm.configure

DBMS_SPM.CREATE_EVOLVE_TASK (

  RETURN VARCHAR2;

DBMS_SPM.CREATE_EVOLVE_TASK (
   plan_list     IN  DBMS_SPM.NAME_LIST,
   time_limit    IN  NUMBER    := DBMS_SPM.AUTO_LIMIT,
   task_name     IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,

  RETURN VARCHAR2;
descriptionText: The function has two overloads, both of which create an advisor task and sets its parameters. This version which takes a SQL handle creates an evolve task in order to evolve one or more plans for a given SQL statement.

name: dbms_spm.create_stgtab_baseline
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.CREATE_STGTAB_BASELINE (

name: dbms_spm.drop_evolve_task
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.DROP_EVOLVE_TASK  (
   task_name        IN  VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: The procedure drops an evolved task.

name: dbms_spm.drop_sql_plan_baseline
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.DROP_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE (
   sql_handle     IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   plan_name      IN VARCHAR2 := NULL)
RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function drops a single plan, or all plans associated with a SQL statement.

name: dbms_spm.evolve_sql_plan_baseline
body:
sql_handle => NULL
	, plan_name => NULL
	, time_limit => DBMS_SPM.AUTO_LIMIT
	, verify => 'YES'
	, commit => 'YES'
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.EVOLVE_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE (
   sql_handle   IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   plan_name    IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   time_limit   IN INTEGER  := DBMS_SPM.AUTO_LIMIT,
   verify       IN VARCHAR2 := 'YES',
   commit       IN VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
  RETURN CLOB;

DBMS_SPM.EVOLVE_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE (
   plan_list    IN DBMS_SPM.NAME_LIST,
   time_limit   IN INTEGER  := DBMS_SPM.AUTO_LIMIT,
   verify       IN VARCHAR2 := 'YES',
   commit       IN VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
  RETURN CLOB;
descriptionText: This function evolves SQL plan baselines associated with one or more SQL statements. A SQL plan baseline is evolved when one or more of its non-accepted plans is changed to an accepted plan or plans. If interrogated by the user (parameter verify =\'YE\'), the execution performance of each non-accepted plan is compared against the performance of a plan chosen from the associated SQL plan baseline. If the non-accepted plan performance is found to be better than SQL plan baseline performance, the non-accepted plan is changed to an accepted plan provided such action is permitted by the user (parameter commit =\'YE\').

name: dbms_spm.execute_evolve_task
descriptionText: The function executes a previously created evolve task.

name: dbms_spm.implement_evolve_task

task_name => $1
	, task_owner => NULL
	, execution_name => NULL
	, force => FALSE
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.IMPLEMENT_EVOLVE_TASK  (
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   task_owner      IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,
   execution_name  IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,
   force           IN BOOLEAN    := FALSE)
 RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: The function implements all the actions recommended by an evolve task.

name: dbms_spm.interrupt_evolve_task
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.INTERRUPT_EVOLVE_TASK  (
   task_name        IN  VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: The procedure interrupts a currently executing evolve task. The task ends its operations as at a normal exit and the user can access the intermediate results. The task can be resumed later.

name: dbms_spm.load_plans_from_cursor_cache
body:
sql_id => $1
	, plan_hash_value => NULL
	, sql_text => $2
	, fixed => 'NO'
	, enabled => 'YES'
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.LOAD_PLANS_FROM_CURSOR_CACHE (
   sql_id            IN  VARCHAR2,
   plan_hash_value   IN  NUMBER   := NULL,
   sql_text          IN  CLOB,
   fixed             IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO',
   enabled           IN  VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
 RETURN PLS_INTEGER;

DBMS_SPM.LOAD_PLANS_FROM_CURSOR_CACHE (
   sql_id            IN  VARCHAR2,
   plan_hash_value   IN  NUMBER   := NULL,
   sql_handle        IN  VARCHAR2,
   fixed             IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO',
   enabled           IN  VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
 RETURN PLS_INTEGER;

DBMS_SPM.LOAD_PLANS_FROM_CURSOR_CACHE (
   sql_id            IN  VARCHAR2,
   plan_hash_value   IN  NUMBER   := NULL,
   fixed             IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO',
   enabled           IN  VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
 RETURN PLS_INTEGER;

DBMS_SPM.LOAD_PLANS_FROM_CURSOR_CACHE (
   attribute_name   IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute_value  IN VARCHAR2,
   fixed            IN VARCHAR2 := 'NO',
   enabled          IN VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
  RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function loads one or more plans present in the cursor cache for a SQL statement, or a set of SQL statements. It has four overloads: using SQL statement text, using SQL handle, using SQL ID, or using attribute_name and attribute_value pair.

name: dbms_spm.load_plans_from_sqlset
body:
sqlset_name => $1
	, sqlset_owner => NULL
	, basic_filter => NULL
	, fixed => 'NO'
	, enabled => 'YES'
	, commit_rows => 1000
bodyNoDefault:
sqlset_name => $1
	, sqlset_owner => $2
	, basic_filter => $3
	, fixed => $4
	, enabled => $5
	, commit_rows => $6
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.LOAD_PLANS_FROM_SQLSET (
   sqlset_name      IN  VARCHAR2,
   sqlset_owner     IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   basic_filter     IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   fixed            IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO',
   enabled          IN  VARCHAR2 := 'YES'
   commit_rows      IN  NUMBER   := 1000)
RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function loads plans stored in a SQL tuning set (STS) into SQL plan baselines. The plans loaded from STS are not verified for performance but added as accepted plans to existing or new SQL plan baselines. This function can be used to seed SQL management base with new SQL plan baselines.

name: dbms_spm.migrate_stored_outline
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.MIGRATE_STORED_OUTLINE (

   attribute_value    IN  CLOB,
   fixed              IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO')
 RETURN CLOB;

DBMS_SPM.MIGRATE_STORED_OUTLINE (
   outln_list         IN  DBMS_SPM.NAME_LIST,
   fixed              IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO')
 RETURN CLOB;
descriptionText: This function migrates stored outlines for one or more SQL statements to plan baselines in the SQL management base (SMB). Users can specify which stored outline(s) to be migrated based on outline name, SQL text, or outline category, or migrate all stored outlines in the system to SQL plan baselines.

name: dbms_sql.bind_array
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.BIND_ARRAY ( 
   c                   IN INTEGER, 
   name                IN VARCHAR2, 
   <table_variable>    IN <datatype> 
 [,index1              IN INTEGER, 
   index2              IN INTEGER)] );
descriptionText: This procedure binds a given value or set of values to a given variable in a cursor, based on the name of the variable in the statement.

name: dbms_sql.bind_variable
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.BIND_VARIABLE (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   name           IN VARCHAR2,
   value          IN <datatype>);
descriptionText: This procedures binds a given value or set of values to a given variable in a cursor, based on the name of the variable in the statement.

name: dbms_sql.close_cursor
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.CLOSE_CURSOR (
   c    IN OUT INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure closes a given cursor.

name: dbms_sql.column_value
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.COLUMN_VALUE (
   c                 IN  INTEGER,
   position          IN  INTEGER,
   value             OUT <datatype> 
 [,column_error      OUT NUMBER] 
 [,actual_length     OUT INTEGER]);
descriptionText: This procedure returns the value of the cursor element for a given position in a given cursor. This procedure is used to access the data fetched by calling FETCH_ROWS.

name: dbms_sql.column_value_long
body:
c => $1
	, position => $2
	, length => $3
	, offset => $4
	, value => $5
	, value_length => $6
bodyNoDefault:
c => $1
	, position => $2
	, length => $3
	, offset => $4
	, value => $5
	, value_length => $6
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.COLUMN_VALUE_LONG (
   c            IN  INTEGER, 
   position     IN  INTEGER, 
   length       IN  INTEGER, 
   offset       IN  INTEGER,
   value        OUT VARCHAR2,
   value_length OUT INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure gets part of the value of a long column.

name: dbms_sql.define_array
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DEFINE_ARRAY (
   c           IN INTEGER, 
   position    IN INTEGER,
   <table_variable>    IN <datatype> 
   cnt         IN INTEGER, 
   lower_bnd   IN INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure defines the collection for column into which you want to fetch rows (with a FETCH_ROWS call). This procedure lets you do batch fetching of rows from a single SELECT statement. A single fetch call brings over a number of rows into the PL/SQL aggregate object.

name: dbms_sql.define_column
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DEFINE_COLUMN (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   position       IN INTEGER,
   column         IN <datatype>);
descriptionText: This procedure defines a column to be selected from the given cursor. This procedure is only used with SELECT cursors.

name: dbms_sql.define_column_char
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DEFINE_COLUMN_CHAR (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   position       IN INTEGER,
   column         IN CHAR CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   column_size    IN INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure defines a column with CHAR data to be selected from the given cursor. This procedure is only used with SELECT cursors.

name: dbms_sql.define_column_long
descriptionText: This procedure defines a LONG column for a SELECT cursor. The column being defined is identified by its relative position in the SELECT list of the statement for the given cursor. The type of the COLUMN value determines the type of the column being defined.

name: dbms_sql.define_column_raw
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DEFINE_COLUMN_RAW (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   position       IN INTEGER,
   column         IN RAW,
   column_size    IN INTEGER);
descriptionText: This procedure defines a column of type RAW to be selected from the given cursor. This procedure is only used with SELECT cursors.

name: dbms_sql.define_column_rowid
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DEFINE_COLUMN_ROWID (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   position       IN INTEGER,
   column         IN ROWID);
descriptionText: This procedure defines a column of type ROWID to be selected from the given cursor. This procedure is only used with SELECT cursors.

name: dbms_sql.describe_columns
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DESCRIBE_COLUMNS ( 
   c              IN  INTEGER, 
   col_cnt        OUT INTEGER, 
   desc_t         OUT DESC_TAB);
descriptionText: This procedure describes the columns for a cursor opened and parsed through DBMS_SQL.

name: dbms_sql.describe_columns2
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DESCRIBE_COLUMNS2 ( 
   c              IN  INTEGER, 
   col_cnt        OUT INTEGER, 
   desc_t         OUT DESC_TAB2);
descriptionText: This procedure describes the specified column. This is an alternative to DESCRIBE_COLUMNS Procedure.

name: dbms_sql.describe_columns3
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DESCRIBE_COLUMNS3 ( 
   c              IN  INTEGER, 
   col_cnt        OUT INTEGER, 
   desc_t         OUT DESC_TAB3);
descriptionText: This procedure describes the specified column. This is an alternative to DESCRIBE_COLUMNS Procedure.

name: dbms_sql.execute
descriptionText: This function executes a given cursor. This function accepts the ID number of the cursor and returns the number of rows processed. The return value is only valid for INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE statements; for other types of statements, including DDL, the return value is undefined and must be ignored.

name: dbms_sql.execute_and_fetch
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.EXECUTE_AND_FETCH (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   exact          IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE)
  RETURN INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function executes the given cursor and fetches rows. This function provides the same functionality as calling EXECUTE and then calling FETCH_ROWS. Calling EXECUTE_AND_FETCH instead, however, may reduce the number of network round-trips when used against a remote database.

name: dbms_sql.fetch_rows
descriptionText: This function fetches a row from a given cursor. You can call FETCH_ROWS repeatedly as long as there are rows remaining to be fetched. These rows are retrieved into a buffer, and must be read by calling COLUMN_VALUE, for each column, after each call to FETCH_ROWS.

name: dbms_sql.get_next_result
descriptionText: This procedure gets the statement of the next result returned to the caller of the recursive statement or, if this caller sets itself as the client for the recursive statement, the next result returned to this caller as client. The statements are returned in same order as they are returned by the RETURN_RESULT Procedures.

name: dbms_sql.is_open
descriptionText: This function checks to see if the given cursor is currently open.

name: dbms_sql.last_error_position
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.LAST_ERROR_POSITION 
   RETURN INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function returns the byte offset in the SQL statement text where the error occurred. The first character in the SQL statement is at position 0.

name: dbms_sql.last_row_count
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.LAST_ROW_COUNT 
   RETURN INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function returns the cumulative count of the number of rows fetched.

name: dbms_sql.last_row_id
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.LAST_ROW_ID 
   RETURN ROWID;
descriptionText: This function returns the ROWID of the last row processed.

name: dbms_sql.last_sql_function_code
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.LAST_SQL_FUNCTION_CODE 
   RETURN INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function returns the SQL function code for the statement. These codes are listed in the Oracle Call Interface Programme\'s Guide.

name: dbms_sql.open_cursor
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.OPEN_CURSOR (
   treat_as_client_for_results    IN     BOOLEAN    DEFAULT FALSE) 
  RETURN INTEGER;

DBMS_SQL.OPEN_CURSOR (
   security_level                 IN     INTEGER,
   treat_as_client_for_results    IN     BOOLEAN    DEFAULT FALSE) 
  RETURN INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function opens a new cursor. The security_level parameter allows for application of fine-grained control to the security of the opened cursor.

   fire_apply_trigger          IN   BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   schema                      IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   container                   IN   VARCHAR2);

   c                           IN   INTEGER,
   statement                   IN   CLOB,
   language_flag               IN   INTEGER,
   edition                     IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   apply_crossedition_trigger  IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   fire_apply_trigger          IN   BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   schema                      IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   container                   IN   VARCHAR2);
DBMS_SQL.PARSE (
   c                           IN   INTEGER, 
   statement                   IN   VARCHAR2A,
   lb                          IN   INTEGER, 
   ub                          IN   INTEGER,
   lfflg                       IN   BOOLEAN, 
   language_flag               IN   INTEGER,
   edition                     IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   apply_crossedition_trigger  IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   fire_apply_trigger          IN   BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,

DBMS_SQL.PARSE (
   c                           IN   INTEGER, 
   statement                   IN   VARCHAR2s,
   lb                          IN   INTEGER, 
   ub                          IN   INTEGER,
   lfflg                       IN   BOOLEAN, 
   language_flag               IN   INTEGER,
   edition                     IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,

   fire_apply_trigger          IN   BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   schema                      IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   container                   IN   VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure parses the given statement in the given cursor. All statements are parsed immediately. In addition, DDL statements are run immediately when parsed.

name: dbms_sql.return_result
descriptionText: This procedure returns the result of an executed statement to the client application.

name: dbms_sql.to_cursor_number
descriptionText: This function takes an OPENed strongly or weakly-typed ref cursor and transforms it into a DBMS_SQL cursor number.

name: dbms_sql.to_refcursor
descriptionText: This function takes an OPENed, PARSEd, and EXECUTEd cursor and transforms/migrates it into a PL/SQL manageable REF CURSOR (a weakly-typed cursor) that can be consumed by PL/SQL native dynamic SQL switched to use native dynamic SQL. This subprogram is only used with SELECT cursors.

name: dbms_sql.variable_value

name: dbms_sql_translator.create_profile

DBMS_SQLTUNE.CAPTURE_CURSOR_CACHE_SQLSET (
    sqlset_name         IN VARCHAR2, 
    time_limit          IN POSITIVE := 1800,
    repeat_interval     IN POSITIVE := 300,
    capture_option      IN VARCHAR2 := 'MERGE',
    capture_mode        IN NUMBER   := MODE_REPLACE_OLD_STATS,

descriptionText: Over a specified time interval this procedure incrementally captures a workload from the shared SQL area into a SQL tuning set. The procedure captures a workload from the shared SQL area into a SQL tuning set, polling the cache multiple times over a time period and updating the workload data stored there. It can execute over as long a period as required to capture an entire system workload.

	, sql_plan => $27
	, bind_list => $28

	, force_matching_signature => $2

	, active_stat_period => $24
	, other => $25
	, plan_hash_value => $26
	, sql_plan => $27
	, bind_list => $28
bodyFullText:
CREATE TYPE sqlset_row AS object (
  sql_id                   VARCHAR(13),
  force_matching_signature NUMBER,
  sql_text                 CLOB,
  object_list              sql_objects,
  bind_data                RAW(2000),
  parsing_schema_name      VARCHAR2(30),
  module                   VARCHAR2(48),
  action                   VARCHAR2(32),
  elapsed_time             NUMBER,
  cpu_time                 NUMBER,
  buffer_gets              NUMBER,
  disk_reads               NUMBER,
  direct_writes            NUMBER,
  rows_processed           NUMBER,
  fetches                  NUMBER,
  executions               NUMBER,
  end_of_fetch_count       NUMBER,
  optimizer_cost           NUMBER,
  optimizer_env            RAW(2000),
  priority                 NUMBER,
  command_type             NUMBER,
  first_load_time          VARCHAR2(19),
  stat_period              NUMBER,
  active_stat_period       NUMBER,
  other                    CLOB,
  plan_hash_value          NUMBER,
  sql_plan                 sql_plan_table_type,
  bind_list                sql_binds)
descriptionText: The SQLSET_ROW object models the content of a SQL tuning set for the user. Logically, a SQL tuning set is a collection of SQLSET_ROWs where each SQLSET_ROW contains a single SQL statement along with its execution context, statistics, binds, and plan. The SELECT_XXX subprograms each model a data source as a collection of SQLSET_ROWs, unique by (sql_id, plan_hash_value). Similarly, the LOAD_SQLSET procedure takes as input a cursor whose row type is SQLSET_ROW, treating each SQLSET_ROW in isolation according to the policies requested by the user.

name: dbms_stats.convert_raw_value
descriptionText: This procedure converts the internal representation of a minimum value, maximum value, or histogram endpoint actual value into a datatype-specific value. The minval, maxval, and eavals fields of the StatRec structure as filled in by GET_COLUMN_STATS or PREPARE_COLUMN_VALUES are appropriate values for input.

name: dbms_stats.convert_raw_value_nvarchar

name: dbms_stats.convert_raw_value_rowid
descriptionText: This procedure converts the internal representation of a a minimum value, maximum value, or histogram end point actual value. The minval, maxval and eavals fields of the StatRec structure as filled in by GET_COLUMN_STATS or PREPARE_COLUMN_VALUES are appropriate values for input.

body:

	, tabname => $2
	, srcpartname => $3
	, dstpartname => $4
	, scale_factor => 1
	, flags => NULL
	, force => FALSE
bodyNoDefault:

	, srcpartname => $3
	, dstpartname => $4
	, scale_factor => $5

bodyFullText:
DBMS_STATS.COPY_TABLE_STATS (
   ownname          VARCHAR2, 
   tabname          VARCHAR2, 
   srcpartname      VARCHAR2,
   dstpartname      VARCHAR2, 
   scale_factor     VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 1,
   flags            NUMBER DEFAULT NULL,
   force            BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
descriptionText: This procedure copies the statistics of the source [sub] partition to the destination [sub] partition. It also copies statistics of all dependent object such as columns and local indexes. If the statistics for source are not available then nothing is copied. It can optionally scale the statistics (such as the number of blks, or number of rows) based on the given scale_factor.

name: dbms_stats.create_extended_stats
bodyFullText:
DBMS_STATS.CREATE_EXTENDED_STATS (
   ownname    VARCHAR2, 
   tabname    VARCHAR2,
   extension  VARCHAR2)
 RETURN VARCHAR2;

DBMS_STATS.CREATE_EXTENDED_STATS (
   ownname    VARCHAR2, 
   tabname    VARCHAR2,
   extension  VARCHAR2)
 RETURN CLOB;
descriptionText: This function creates a column statistics entry in the system for a user specified column group or an expression in a table. Statistics for this extension will be gathered when user or auto statistics gathering job gathers statistics for the table. We call statistics for such an extension, "extended statistics". This function returns the name of this newly created entry for the extension.

name: dbms_stats.flush_database_monitoring_info
bodyFullText: DBMS_STATS.FLUSH_DATABASE_MONITORING_INFO;
descriptionText: This procedure flushes in-memory monitoring information for all tables in the dictionary. Corresponding entries in the *_TAB_MODIFICATIONS, *_TAB_STATISTICS and *_IND_STATISTICS views are updated immediately, without waiting for the Oracle database to flush them periodically. This procedure is useful when you need up-to-date information in those views. Because the GATHER_*_STATS procedures internally flush monitoring information, it is not necessary to run this procedure before gathering the statistics.

descriptionText: This procedure gathers index statistics. It attempts to parallelize as much of the work as possible. Restrictions are described in the individual parameters. This operation will not parallelize with certain types of indexes, including cluster indexes, domain indexes, and bitmap join indexes. The granularity and no_invalidate arguments are not relevant to these types of indexes.

   method_opt           IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT GET_PARAM('METHOD_OPT'),
   degree               IN    NUMBER     DEFAULT TO_DEGREE_TYPE(
                                           GET_PARAM('DEGREE')), 
   granularity          IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT GET_PARAM('GRANULARITY'), 
   cascade              IN    BOOLEAN    DEFAULT to_cascade_type (
                                           GET_PARAM('CASCADE')),

   detail_level         IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT 'TYPICAL',
   format               IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT 'TEXT') 
 RETURN CLOB;
descriptionText: This function runs the GATHER_DATABASE_STATS Procedures in reporting mode. That is, statistics are not actually collected, but all the objects that will be affected when GATHER_DATABASE_STATS is invoked are reported. The input set of parameters are exactly the same as in GATHER_DATABASE_STATS with two extra parameters.

   estimate_percent      IN    NUMBER     DEFAULT TO_ESTIMATE_PERCENT_TYPE 
                                                (GET_PARAM('ESTIMATE_PERCENT')),
   block_sample          IN    BOOLEAN    DEFAULT FALSE,
   method_opt            IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT GET_PARAM('METHOD_OPT'),
   degree                IN    NUMBER     DEFAULT TO_DEGREE_TYPE 
                                                (GET_PARAM('DEGREE')),
   granularity           IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT GET_PARAM('GRANULARITY'),
   cascade               IN    BOOLEAN    DEFAULT TO_CASCADE_TYPE
                                                (GET_PARAM('CASCADE')),
   stattab               IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL, 
   statid                IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL,
   options               IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT 'GATHER AUTO', 
   statown               IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL,
   no_invalidate         IN    BOOLEAN    DEFAULT TO_NO_INVALIDATE_TYPE
                                                (GET_PARAM('NO_INVALIDATE')),
   detail_level          IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT 'TYPICAL',
   format                IN    VARCHAR2   DEFAULT 'TEXT') 
 RETURN CLOB;
descriptionText: This function runs the GATHER_DICTIONARY_STATS Procedure in reporting mode. That is, statistics are not actually collected, but all objects affected when GATHER_DICTIONARY_STATS is invoked are reported. The input set of parameters are exactly the same as in GATHER_DICTIONARY_STATS with two extra parameters.

   opid              NUMBER,

descriptionText: This function generates a report for the provided operation optionally in a particular pluggable database (PDB) in a multitenant environment.

body:
detail_level => 'TYPICAL'
	, format => 'TEXT'
	, latestN => NULL
	, since => NULL
	, until => NULl
	, auto_only => FALSE
	, container_ids => DBMS_STATS.NULL_NUMTAB
bodyNoDefault:
detail_level => $1
	, format => $2
	, latestN => $3
	, since => $4

bodyFullText:
DBMS_STATS.REPORT_STATS_OPERATIONS (
   detail_level       VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'TYPICAL',
   format             VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'TEXT',
   latestN            NUMBER DEFAULT NULL,
   since              TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NULL,
   until              TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NULl,
   auto_only          BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   container_ids      DBMS_UTILITY.NUMBER_ARRAY DEFAULT DBMS_STATS.NULL_NUMTAB)
 RETURN CLOB;
descriptionText: This function generates a report of all statistics operations that take place between two timestamps which may or may not have been provided. It allows the scope of the report to be narrowed down so that report will include only auto statistics gathering runs. Furthermore, in a multitenant environment, users may optionally provide a set of pluggable database (PDB) IDs so that only statistics operations from the specified pluggable databases will be reported.

name: dbms_stats.seed_col_usage
bodyFullText:
DBMS_STATS.SEED_COL_USAGE (
   sqlset_name    IN    VARCHAR2,
   owner_name     IN    VARCHAR2,
   time_limit     IN    POSITIVE DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure seeds column usage information from a statements in the specified SQL tuning set. It iterates over the SQL statements in the specified SQL tuning set, compiles them and seeds column usage information for the columns that appear in these statements. You can monitor the workload on the system for given amount of time and seed the and seed the column usage information based on the columns that appear in statements executed during the monitoring window.

name: dbms_storage_map.lock_map
bodyFullText: DBMS_STORAGE_MAP.LOCK_MAP;
descriptionText: This procedure locks the mapping information in the shared memory of the instance. This is useful when you need a consistent snapshot of the V$MAP tables. Without locking the mapping information, V$MAP_ELEMENT and V$MAP_SUBELEMENT, for example, may be inconsistent.

name: dbms_storage_map.map_all
descriptionText: This function builds the entire mapping information for all types of Oracle files (except archive logs), including all directed acyclic graph (DAG) elements. It obtains the latest mapping information because it explicitly synchronizes all mapping libraries.

name: dbms_storage_map.map_element
bodyFullText:
DBMS_STORAGE_MAP.MAP_ELEMENT(
   elemname          IN VARCHAR2,
   cascade           IN BOOLEAN,
   dictionary_update IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE);
descriptionText: This function builds mapping information for the element identified by elemname. It may not obtain the latest mapping information if the element being mapped, or any one of the elements within its I/O stack (if cascade is TRUE), is owned by a library that must be explicitly synchronized.

name: dbms_storage_map.map_file
body:
filename => $1
	, filetype => $2
	, cascade => $3
	, max_num_fileextent => 100
	, dictionary_update => TRUE
bodyFullText:
DBMS_STORAGE_MAP.MAP_FILE(
   filename           IN VARCHAR2, 
   filetype           IN VARCHAR2,
   cascade            IN BOOLEAN,
   max_num_fileextent IN NUMBER DEFAULT 100,
   dictionary_update  IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE);
descriptionText: This function builds mapping information for the file identified by filename. Use this function if the mapping of one particular file has changed. The Oracle database server does not have to rebuild the entire mapping.

name: dbms_storage_map.map_object
bodyFullText:
DBMS_STORAGE_MAP.MAP_OBJECT(
   objname  IN  VARCHAR2,
   owner    IN  VARCHAR2,
   objtype  IN  VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This function builds the mapping information for the Oracle object identified by the object name, owner, and type.

name: dbms_storage_map.restore
bodyFullText: DBMS_STORAGE_MAP.RESTORE;
descriptionText: This function loads the entire mapping information from the data dictionary into the shared memory of the instance. You can invoke RESTORE only after a SAVE operation. You must explicitly call RESTORE in a warm startup scenario.

name: dbms_storage_map.save
bodyFullText: DBMS_STORAGE_MAP.SAVE;
descriptionText: This function saves information needed to regenerate the entire mapping into the data dictionary.

name: dbms_storage_map.unlock_map
bodyFullText: DBMS_STORAGE_MAP.UNLOCK_MAP;
descriptionText: This procedure unlocks the mapping information in the shared memory of the instance.

name: dbms_streams.convert_anydata_to_lcr_ddl
descriptionText: This function converts a ANYDATA object into a SYS.LCR$_DDL_RECORD object.

name: dbms_streams.convert_anydata_to_lcr_row
descriptionText: This function converts a ANYDATA object into a SYS.LCR$_ROW_RECORD object.

name: dbms_streams.convert_lcr_to_xml
descriptionText: This function converts a logical change record (LCR) encapsulated in a ANYDATA object into an XML object that conforms to the XML schema for LCRs. The LCR can be a row LCR or a DDL LCR.

name: dbms_streams.convert_xml_to_lcr
descriptionText: This function converts an XML object that conforms to the XML schema for logical change records (LCRs) into an LCR encapsulated in a ANYDATA object. The LCR can be a row or DDL LCR.

name: dbms_streams.get_information
descriptionText: This function returns information about various Oracle Streams attributes.

name: dbms_streams.get_streams_name
bodyFullText:
DBMS_STREAMS.GET_STREAMS_NAME
RETURN VARCHAR2;
descriptionText: This function gets the Oracle Streams name of the invoker if the invoker is one of the following Oracle Streams types:

name: dbms_streams.get_streams_type
bodyFullText:
DBMS_STREAMS.GET_STREAMS_TYPE
RETURN VARCHAR2;
descriptionText: This function gets the Oracle Streams type of the invoker and returns one of the following types:

name: dbms_streams.get_tag
bodyFullText:
DBMS_STREAMS.GET_TAG
RETURN RAW;
descriptionText: This function gets the binary tag for all redo entries generated by the current session.

name: dbms_streams.max_compatible
bodyFullText:
DBMS_STREAMS.MAX_COMPATIBLE
RETURN INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function returns an integer that is greater than the highest possible compatibility constant for the current release of Oracle Database.

name: dbms_streams.set_tag
bodyFullText:
DBMS_STREAMS.SET_TAG(
   tag  IN  RAW  DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure sets the binary tag for all redo entries subsequently generated by the current session. Each redo entry generated by DML or DDL statements in the current session has this tag. This procedure affects only the current session.

body:
rule_name => $1
	, table_name => $2
	, column_name => $3
	, column_value => $4
	, value_type => 'NEW'
	, step_number => 0
	, operation => 'ADD'

	, operation => $7

   rule_name     IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_name    IN  VARCHAR2,
   column_name   IN  VARCHAR2,
   column_value  IN  ANYDATA,
   value_type    IN  VARCHAR2     DEFAULT 'NEW',
   step_number   IN  NUMBER       DEFAULT 0,
   operation     IN  VARCHAR2     DEFAULT 'ADD');
DBMS_STREAMS_ADM.ADD_COLUMN(
   rule_name        IN  VARCHAR2,
   table_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   column_name      IN  VARCHAR2,
   column_function  IN  VARCHAR2,
   value_type       IN  VARCHAR2     DEFAULT 'NEW',
   step_number      IN  NUMBER       DEFAULT 0,
   operation        IN  VARCHAR2     DEFAULT 'ADD');
descriptionText: This procedure either adds or removes a declarative rule-based transformation which adds a column to a row logical change record (row LCR) that satisfies the specified rule.

This procedure can either perform these actions directly, or it can generate a script that performs these actions. Run this procedure at the source database.

name: dbms_streams_adm.recover_operation
descriptionText: This procedure provides options for operations that stopped because they encountered an errors. These operations include split and merge operations, Oracle Streams replication configuration operations, and Oracle Streams change table configuration operations. This procedure either rolls forward the operation, rolls back the operation, or purges all of the metadata about the operation.

name: dbms_streams_adm.set_message_tracking
descriptionText: Sets the tracking label for logical change records (LCRs) produced by the current session. This procedure affects only the current session. Any LCRs produced by the current session are tracked, including captured LCRs and persistent LCRs.

name: dbms_sync_refresh.abort_refresh
descriptionText: This procedure undoes all the changes made by PREPARE_REFRESH or EXECUTE_REFRESH for the specified sync refresh groups. It helps you to recover to a state where the tables and materialized views are usable and consistent in case they encounter unexpected errors.

name: dbms_sync_refresh.alter_refresh_stats_retention
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SYNC_REFRESH.ALTER_REFRESH_STATS_RETENTION (
   retention   IN NUMBER);
descriptionText: This procedure alters the refresh history retention value, specified in days. It is intended for use in conjunction with PURGE_REFRESH_HISTORY. It also requires the SYSDBA privilege in addition to the privilege to execute it.

name: dbms_sync_refresh.can_syncref_table
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SYNC_REFRESH.CAN_SYNCREF_TABLE (
    schema_name    IN VARCHAR2,
    table_name     IN VARCHAR2,
    statement_id   IN VARCHAR2);

DBMS_SYNC_REFRESH.CAN_SYNCREF_TABLE (
    schema_name    IN VARCHAR2,
    table_name     IN VARCHAR2,
    output_array   IN OUT Sys.CanSyncRefTypeArray);
descriptionText: This procedure advises on whether a table and its dependent materialized views are eligible for sync refresh. It provides an explanation of its analysis. If not eligible, you can examine the reasons and take appropriate action if possible.

name: dbms_sync_refresh.execute_refresh
descriptionText: This procedure executes sync refresh on the sync refresh groups prepared by DBMS_SYNC_REFRESH.PREPARE_REFRESH. These groups are identified by their group IDs. Note this procedure will only perform the refresh on those materialized views that have been registered for synch refresh; any other materialized views will become stale once this procedure completes.

name: dbms_sync_refresh.get_all_group_ids
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SYNC_REFRESH.GET_ALL_GROUP_IDS
           RETURN DBMS_UTILITY.NUMBER_ARRAY;
descriptionText: This function returns the group IDs of all the sync refresh groups in the database.

name: dbms_sync_refresh.get_group_id
descriptionText: This function returns the group ID of a materialized view. The group ID identifies the sync refresh group the table belongs to. A sync refresh group is a group of related tables and their dependent materialized views which must be all refreshed together jointly to ensure consistency and correctness.

name: dbms_sync_refresh.get_group_id_list
descriptionText: This function returns the group IDs of the tables in a given list of objects (materialized views).

name: dbms_sync_refresh.prepare_refresh
descriptionText: This procedure prepares for refresh the sync refresh groups identified by the group ID in the input. A sync refresh group consists of a set of related tables and all materialized views dependent on those base tables. Note this procedure will only prepare for refresh those dependent materialized views that have been registered for synchronous refresh.

name: dbms_sync_refresh.prepare_staging_log
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SYNC_REFRESH.PREPARE_STAGING_LOG (
   schema_name      IN VARCHAR2,
   base_table_name  IN VARCHAR2,
   psl_mode         IN NUMBER DEFAULT
   DBMS_SYNC_REFRESH.ENFORCED);
descriptionText: This procedure collects statistics on the data in the staging log of the base table and validates the data in the log. It can be run in several different modes ranging from the enforced mode in which strict checking of the data is done to trusted mode in which no checking is done. You should run this procedure after loading the staging log and before running PREPARE_REFRESH.

name: dbms_sync_refresh.purge_refresh_stats
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SYNC_REFRESH.PURGE_REFRESH_STATS (
   before_timestamp IN TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE);
descriptionText: This procedure purges the refresh history of sync refreshes that took place before the value specified by the BEFORE_TIMESTAMP parameter. This procedure requires the SYSDBA privilege in addition to the privilege to execute it.

name: dbms_sync_refresh.register_mviews
bodyFullText:
DBMS_SYNC_REFRESH.REGISTER_MVIEWS (
   mv_list   IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure registers a list of materialized views for synchronous refresh. It checks each materialized view in the list for eligibility and places it in the sync refresh group it belongs to. A sync refresh group is a set of related tables and materialized views defined on top of them. Two tables are considered related if there is a referential constraint between them.

name: dbms_transaction.local_transaction_id
descriptionText: This function returns the local (to instance) unique identifier for the current transaction. It returns null if there is no current transaction.

name: dbms_transaction.purge_lost_db_entry
bodyFullText:
DBMS_TRANSACTION.PURGE_LOST_DB_ENTRY (
   xid VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: When a failure occurs during commit processing, automatic recovery consistently resolves the results at all sites involved in the transaction. However, if the remote database is destroyed or re-created before recovery completes, then the entries used to control recovery in DBA_2PC_PENDING and associated tables are never removed, and recovery will periodically retry. Procedure PURGE_LOST_DB_ENTRY enables removal of such transactions from the local site.

name: dbms_transaction.purge_mixed
bodyFullText:
DBMS_TRANSACTION.PURGE_MIXED (
   xid VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: When in-doubt transactions are forced to commit or rollback (instead of letting automatic recovery resolve their outcomes), there is a possibility that a transaction can have a mixed outcome: Some sites commit, and others rollback. Such inconsistency cannot be resolved automatically by Oracle; however, Oracle flags entries in DBA_2PC_PENDING by setting the MIXED column to a value of\'ye\'.

DBMS_UTILITY.COMMA_TO_TABLE ( 
   list   IN  VARCHAR2,
   tablen OUT BINARY_INTEGER,
   tab    OUT lname_array);
descriptionText: These procedures converts a comma-delimited list of names into a PL/SQL table of names. The second version supports fully-qualified attribute names.

name: dbms_utility.compile_schema
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.COMPILE_SCHEMA (
   schema          IN VARCHAR2,
   compile_all     IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   reuse_settings  IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
descriptionText: This procedure compiles all procedures, functions, packages, views and triggers in the specified schema.

name: dbms_utility.create_alter_type_error_table
descriptionText: This procedure creates an error table to be used in the EXCEPTION clause of the ALTER TYPE statement.

name: dbms_utility.current_instance
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.CURRENT_INSTANCE
   RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function returns the current connected instance number. It returns NULL when connected instance is down.

name: dbms_utility.data_block_address_block
descriptionText: This function gets the block number part of a data block address.

name: dbms_utility.data_block_address_file
descriptionText: This function gets the file number part of a data block address.

name: dbms_utility.db_version
descriptionText: This procedure returns version information for the database.

name: dbms_utility.exec_ddl_statement
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.EXEC_DDL_STATEMENT (
   parse_string IN VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure executes the DDL statement in parse_string.

name: dbms_utility.expand_sql_text
descriptionText: This procedure recursively replaces any view references in the input SQL query with the corresponding view subquery.

name: dbms_utility.format_call_stack
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.FORMAT_CALL_STACK 
  RETURN VARCHAR2;
descriptionText: This function formats the current call stack. This can be used on any stored procedure or trigger to access the call stack. This can be useful for debugging.

name: dbms_utility.format_error_backtrace
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.FORMAT_ERROR_BACKTRACE 
  RETURN VARCHAR2;
descriptionText: This function displays the call stack at the point where an exception was raised, even if the subprogram is called from an exception handler in an outer scope. The output is similar to the output of the SQLERRM function, but not subject to the same size limitation.

name: dbms_utility.format_error_stack
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.FORMAT_ERROR_STACK 
  RETURN VARCHAR2;
descriptionText: This function formats the current error stack. This can be used in exception handlers to look at the full error stack.

name: dbms_utility.get_cpu_time
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.GET_CPU_TIME
   RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function returns a measure of current CPU processing time in hundredths of a second. The difference between the times returned from two calls measures the CPU processing time (not the total elapsed time) between those two points.

name: dbms_utility.get_dependency
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.GET_DEPENDENCY
   type      IN     VARCHAR2,
   schema    IN     VARCHAR2,
   name      IN     VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure shows the dependencies on the object passed in.

name: dbms_utility.get_endianness
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.GET_ENDIANNESS
   RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function gets the endianness of the database platform.

name: dbms_utility.get_hash_value
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.GET_HASH_VALUE (
   name      VARCHAR2, 
   base      NUMBER, 
   hash_size NUMBER)
  RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function computes a hash value for the given string.

name: dbms_utility.get_parameter_value
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.GET_PARAMETER_VALUE (
   parnam     IN        VARCHAR2,
   intval     IN OUT    BINARY_INTEGER,
   strval     IN OUT    VARCHAR2,
   listno     IN        BINARY_INTEGER DEFAULT 1)
  RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
descriptionText: This function gets the value of specified init.ora parameter.

name: dbms_utility.get_sql_hash
bodyFullText:
Dbms_utility.get_sql_hash (
   name          IN   VARCHAR2,    
   hash          OUT  RAW,    
   pre10ihash    OUT  NUMBER) 
  RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function computes a hash value for the given string using MD5 algorithm.

name: dbms_utility.get_time
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.GET_TIME 
  RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function determines the current time in 100t\'s of a second. This subprogram is primarily used for determining elapsed time. The subprogram is called twice – at the beginning and end of some process – and then the first (earlier) number is subtracted from the second (later) number to determine the time elapsed.

name: dbms_utility.get_tz_transitions
descriptionText: This procedure returns time zone transitions by regionid from the timezone.dat file.

name: dbms_utility.invalidate
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.INVALIDATE ( 
   p_object_id              NUMBER,
   p_plsql_object_settings  VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   p_option_flags           PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT 0);
descriptionText: This procedure invalidates a database object and (optionally) modifies its PL/SQL compiler parameter settings. It also invalidates any objects that (directly or indirectly) depend on the object being invalidated.

name: dbms_utility.is_bit_set
descriptionText: This function checks the bit setting for the given bit in the given RAW value.

name: dbms_utility.is_cluster_database
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.IS_CLUSTER_DATABASE 
  RETURN BOOLEAN;
descriptionText: This function finds out if this database is running in cluster database mode.

name: dbms_utility.make_data_block_address
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.MAKE_DATA_BLOCK_ADDRESS (
   file  NUMBER, 
   block NUMBER) 
  RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function creates a data block address given a file number and a block number. A data block address is the internal structure used to identify a block in the database. This function is useful when accessing certain fixed tables that contain data block addresses.

DBMS_UTILITY.OLD_CURRENT_SCHEMA

DBMS_UTILITY.OLD_CURRENT_USER 
 RETURN VARCHAR2;

name: dbms_utility.port_string

DBMS_UTILITY.PORT_STRING 
   RETURN VARCHAR2;

name: dbms_utility.sqlid_to_sqlhash
descriptionText: This function converts a SQL ID into a hash value.

name: dbms_utility.table_to_comma
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.TABLE_TO_COMMA ( 
   tab    IN  UNCL_ARRAY, 
   tablen OUT BINARY_INTEGER,
   list   OUT VARCHAR2);

DBMS_UTILITY.TABLE_TO_COMMA ( 
   tab    IN  lname_array,
   tablen OUT BINARY_INTEGER,
   list   OUT VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: This procedure converts a PL/SQL table of names into a comma-delimited list of names. This takes a PL/SQL table, 1..n, terminated with n+1 null. The second version supports fully-qualified attribute names.

name: dbms_utility.validate
descriptionText: This procedure makes invalid database objects valid.

name: dbms_utility.wait_on_pending_dml
bodyFullText:
DBMS_UTILITY.WAIT_ON_PENDING_DML (
    tables     IN       VARCHAR2,
    timeout    IN       BINARY_INTEGER,
    scn        IN OUT   NUMBER)
  RETURN BOOLEAN;
descriptionText: This function waits until all transactions (other than the calle\'s own) that have locks on the listed tables and began prior to the specified scn have either committed or been rolled back.

name: dbms_warning.add_warning_setting_cat
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WARNING.ADD_WARNING_SETTING_CAT (
   warning_category    IN    VARCHAR2,
   warning_value       IN    VARCHAR2,
   scope               IN    VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: You can modify the current sessio\'s or syste\'s warning settings with the value supplied. The value will be added to the existing parameter setting if the value for the warning_category or warning_value has not been set, or override the existing value. The effect of calling this function is same as adding the qualifier (ENABLE/DISABLE/ERROR) on the category specified to the end of the current session or system setting.

name: dbms_warning.add_warning_setting_num
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WARNING.ADD_WARNING_SETTING_NUM (
   warning_number      IN    NUMBER,
   warning_value       IN    VARCHAR2,
   scope               IN    VARCHAR2);
descriptionText: You can modify the current session or system warning settings with the value supplied. If the value was already set, you will override the existing value. The effect of calling this function is same as adding the qualifier (ENABLE / DISABLE/ ERROR) on the category specified to the end of the current session or system setting.

name: dbms_warning.get_category
descriptionText: This function returns the category name, given the message number.

name: dbms_warning.get_warning_setting_cat
descriptionText: This function returns the specific warning category setting for the current session.

name: dbms_warning.get_warning_setting_num
descriptionText: This function returns the specific warning number setting for the current session.

name: dbms_warning.get_warning_setting_string
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WARNING.GET_WARNING_SETTING_STRING
 RETURN VARCHAR2;
descriptionText: This function returns the entire warning string for the current session.

name: dbms_warning.set_warning_setting_string
descriptionText: This procedure replaces previous settings with the new value. The warning string may contain mix of category and warning numbers using the same syntax as used on the right hand side of\'\' when issuing an ALTER SESSION or SYSTEM SET PLSQL_WARNINGS command. This will have same effect as ALTER SESSION OR ALTER SYSTEM command.

name: dbms_wm.addasparentworkspace
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WM.AddAsParentWorkspace(

name: dbms_wm.adduserdefinedhint
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WM.AddUserDefinedHint(
   hint_id   IN NUMBER,
   table_id  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   hint      IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: Adds a user-defined hint: that is, modifies (and thus overrides) a default optimizer hint, with the goal of improving the performance of SQL statements executed by the DBMS_WM package on a specified version-enabled table or all version-enabled tables.

name: dbms_wm.altersavepoint
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WM.AlterSavepoint(

	, remove_latest_deleted_rows => $7

   workspace                   IN VARCHAR2,

body:
workspace => $1
	, compress_view_wo_overwrite => FALSE
	, auto_commit => TRUE
	, commit_in_batches => FALSE
	, batch_size => 'PRIMARY_KEY_RANGE'
	, remove_latest_deleted_rows => FALSE
bodyNoDefault:
workspace => $1
	, compress_view_wo_overwrite => $2
	, auto_commit => $3
	, commit_in_batches => $4
	, batch_size => $5
	, remove_latest_deleted_rows => $6
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WM.CompressWorkspaceTree(
   workspace                   IN VARCHAR2,
   compress_view_wo_overwrite  IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,

   batch_size                  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'PRIMARY_KEY_RANGE',

descriptionText: Deletes removable savepoints in a workspace and all its descendant workspaces. (Removable savepoints are explained in Section 1.1.2.) It also minimizes the Workspace Manager metadata structures for the affected workspaces, and eliminates any redundant data that might arise from the deletion of the savepoints.

name: dbms_wm.setwmvalidupdatemodeon

name: dbms_wm.setwooverwriteon

descriptionText: Enables the VIEW_WO_OVERWRITE history option that was disabled by the SetWoOverwriteOFF procedure.

name: dbms_workload_replay.add_filter
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WORKLOAD_REPLAY.ADD_FILTER (
   fname          IN VARCHAR2,

DBMS_WORKLOAD_REPLAY.ADD_FILTER (
   fname          IN VARCHAR2,
   fattribute     IN VARCHAR2,
   fvalue         IN NUMBER);

name: dbms_workload_replay.add_schedule_ordering
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WORKLOAD_REPLAY.ADD_SCHEDULE_ORDERING (
   schedule_capture_id     IN VARCHAR2,
   waitfor_capture_id      IN VARCHAR2)
  RETURN NUMBER;
descriptionText: This function adds a schedule order between two captures. Together, schedule_capture_id and waitfor_capture_id form a schedule ordering that previously added by the ADD_SCHEDULE_ORDERING Function. The order is that replay of capture indicated by schedule_capture_id will not start unless the replay of capture indicated by waiting_for_capture_id finishes.

name: dbms_workload_replay.begin_replay_schedule
descriptionText: This procedure initiates the creation of a reusable replay schedule.

name: dbms_workload_replay.calibrate
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WORKLOAD_REPLAY.CALIBRATE (
   capture_dir          IN VARCHAR2,
   process_per_cpu      IN BINARY_INTEGER DEFAULT 4,
   threads_per_process  IN BINARY_INTEGER DEFAULT 50)
  RETURN CLOB;
descriptionText: This function operates on a processed workload capture directory to estimate the number of hosts and workload replay clients needed to faithfully replay the given workload. This function returns the results as an XML CLOB.

name: dbms_workload_replay.cancel_replay
bodyFullText:
DBMS_WORKLOAD_REPLAY.CANCEL_REPLAY (
   error_msg    IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
descriptionText: This procedure cancels workload replay in progress. All the external replay clients (WRC) will automatically be notified to stop issuing the captured workload and exit.
